meta.title: Islamic Studies MCQs - Basic Beliefs in Islam (Aqidah)
meta.description: Practice questions on Basic Beliefs in Islam.
meta.keywords: islamic studies, mcqs, quiz, basic beliefs, aqidah, islam

questions.q: What is the fundamental belief in Islam regarding the nature of God?
options: God is part of a trinity
God is present in multiple forms
questions.ex: Tawhid, the oneness and uniqueness of Allah, is the most fundamental belief in Islam.

questions.q: What is the Arabic term for 'belief' or 'creed' in Islam?
questions.ex: Aqidah refers to the fundamental beliefs and tenets of Islam.

questions.q: Belief in the Messengers of Allah is a pillar of:
questions.ex: Belief in the Messengers is one of the six pillars of Iman (faith) in Islam.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT one of the six pillars of Iman (faith) in Islam?
options: Belief in the Day of Judgment
questions.ex: Giving Zakat is a pillar of Islam (practice), not a pillar of Iman (faith).

questions.q: What does the belief in the Day of Judgment (Qiyamah) entail?
options: Humans will be resurrected and judged by Allah
Only good people will be resurrected
questions.ex: Belief in Qiyamah is the belief that all humans will be resurrected and judged by Allah for their deeds in this life.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of prophets and messengers in Islam?
options: To guide humanity to the worship of Allah and convey His message
questions.ex: Prophets and messengers were sent by Allah to guide humanity towards worshipping Him alone and to convey His divine message.

questions.q: Which belief signifies that everything that happens is according to Allah's knowledge and will?
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar (Divine Decree and Destiny) means believing that everything happens according to Allah's prior knowledge and will.

questions.q: What is the significance of believing in the Divine Books?
options: They are revelations from Allah containing guidance for humanity
questions.ex: Divine Books (like the Quran, Torah, Gospel, Psalms) are believed to be revelations from Allah, providing guidance for humanity.

questions.q: Which of the following best describes the concept of Tawhid?
options: Belief in the oneness and uniqueness of Allah
Belief in the power of nature
questions.ex: Tawhid is the absolute belief in the oneness and uniqueness of Allah, rejecting any partners or equals to Him.

questions.q: What are angels made of?
questions.ex: Muslims believe that angels are created from light (Noor).

questions.q: What is the role of angels in Islam?
options: To act as messengers of Allah and carry out His commands
questions.ex: Angels serve as messengers of Allah, carrying out His commands and performing various tasks.

questions.q: Which of the following is a major angel known as the bringer of revelation?
questions.ex: Jibril (Gabriel) is the archangel responsible for delivering Allah's revelations to the prophets.

questions.q: What does belief in the unseen (Ghaib) mean in Islam?
options: Believing in things that are not visible to the human eye but are mentioned in the Quran and Sunnah
questions.ex: Belief in the unseen includes believing in things like angels, jinn, Paradise, and Hell, which are not visible but are part of Islamic belief based on the Quran and Sunnah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the origin of the universe?
options: It evolved naturally without any creator
questions.ex: Muslims believe that the universe and everything in it was created by Allah.

questions.q: What is the concept of 'Risalah' in Islam?
options: Belief in the oneness of God
questions.ex: Risalah refers to the concept of prophethood and the belief in the messengers sent by Allah.

questions.q: What is the final Divine Book revealed by Allah?
questions.ex: Muslims believe the Holy Quran is the final and complete revelation from Allah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief regarding the authenticity of the Holy Quran?
options: It has been altered over time
It is the literal and preserved word of Allah
It is a collection of human writings
questions.ex: Muslims believe the Quran is the unadulterated and preserved word of Allah.

questions.q: What is the concept of 'Akhirah' in Islam?
questions.ex: Akhirah refers to the hereafter or the afterlife, including the Day of Judgment, Paradise, and Hell.

questions.q: What does belief in the Divine Decree and Destiny (Qada and Qadar) NOT mean?
options: That humans have no free will
That everything is predetermined by Allah
That Allah has knowledge of everything that will happen
That humans are accountable for their actions
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar acknowledges Allah's knowledge and will, but it does not negate human free will and accountability for their choices.

questions.q: What is the purpose of trials and tribulations in this life according to Islamic belief?
options: They are tests from Allah to strengthen faith and purify believers
They are a sign of Allah's displeasure
questions.ex: Trials and tribulations are seen as tests from Allah to strengthen the faith of believers, purify them, and increase their reward.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the first human created by Allah?
questions.ex: Muslims believe that Adam (peace be upon him) was the first human created by Allah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the nature of Iblis (Satan)?
options: He is a jinn who disobeyed Allah
questions.ex: Iblis is believed to be a jinn who refused to prostrate to Adam and was consequently expelled from Paradise.

questions.q: What is the significance of believing in all the prophets sent by Allah?
options: Only believing in Prophet Muhammad is sufficient
Each prophet brought a different religion
They all conveyed the same core message of worshipping Allah alone
Some prophets are more important to believe in than others
questions.ex: Muslims believe in all the prophets sent by Allah, as they all conveyed the fundamental message of Tawhid (oneness of God).

questions.q: What is the Islamic term for worshipping Allah alone, without associating partners with Him?
questions.ex: Ibadah encompasses all acts of worship dedicated solely to Allah.

questions.q: What is 'Shirk' in Islam?
options: Associating partners with Allah in worship
questions.ex: Shirk is the grave sin of associating partners with Allah in worship, which is the opposite of Tawhid.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the purpose of human creation?
questions.ex: The primary purpose of human creation, according to the Quran, is to worship Allah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the concept of 'Fitrah'?
options: It is the ability to sin
It is the innate human disposition towards believing in Allah
It is the result of upbringing
questions.ex: Fitrah is the natural inclination or innate disposition of humans to recognize and believe in their Creator, Allah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic understanding of 'Barzakh'?
options: The state between death and resurrection
questions.ex: Barzakh is the intermediate state or barrier between worldly life and the afterlife, where souls reside after death until the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the concept of 'Shafa'ah'?
options: Intercession on the Day of Judgment
questions.ex: Shafa'ah refers to the intercession that will take place on the Day of Judgment, by the permission of Allah.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the record of deeds?
options: All deeds, good and bad, are recorded by angels
questions.ex: Muslims believe that two angels (Kiraman Katibin) record all the deeds of humans, both good and bad.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the balance of deeds on the Day of Judgment?
options: Good deeds will be weighed against bad deeds
questions.ex: On the Day of Judgment, a person's good deeds will be weighed against their bad deeds to determine their destination in the afterlife.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about Paradise (Jannah)?
options: It is a place of eternal reward for believers
It is a spiritual state only
questions.ex: Jannah is believed to be a place of eternal bliss and reward for those who believed in Allah and did righteous deeds.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about Hellfire (Jahannam)?
options: It is a place of eternal punishment for disbelievers and sinners
It is only for the worst of sinners
questions.ex: Jahannam is believed to be a place of eternal punishment for those who disbelieved in Allah and committed major sins.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the bridge over Hellfire (Sirat)?
options: It is a physical bridge everyone must cross
It is a test on the Day of Judgment that determines one's path to Paradise or Hell
Only the righteous will see it
questions.ex: Sirat is believed to be a bridge that all souls will attempt to cross on the Day of Judgment. Its ease of crossing depends on one's deeds.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the encounter with Allah on the Day of Judgment?
options: Humans will be judged directly by Allah
Humans will be judged by angels
questions.ex: Muslims believe that on the Day of Judgment, each individual will stand before Allah to be judged.

questions.q: What is the Islamic belief about the role of free will in relation to Divine Decree?
options: Humans have complete free will independent of Allah's will
Humans have limited free will within the framework of Allah's knowledge and will
questions.ex: Islamic belief balances Divine Decree with human free will. Allah has knowledge of everything, but humans still have the capacity to make choices for which they are accountable.

questions.q: Which of the following is the first pillar of Islam?
questions.ex: The Shahada, the declaration of faith, is the foundational and first pillar of Islam.

questions.q: How many times a day are Muslims required to perform Salat?
questions.ex: Muslims are required to pray five times a day at specific times.

questions.q: What is the Arabic term for the compulsory charitable giving in Islam?
questions.ex: Zakat is the mandatory charity that Muslims are required to pay annually on their wealth.

questions.q: During which Islamic month is fasting (Sawm) observed?
questions.ex: Sawm, the obligatory fasting, is performed during the month of Ramadan.

questions.q: The pilgrimage to Mecca, which is one of the Five Pillars, is known as:
questions.ex: Hajj is the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, required of every Muslim who is able to undertake it.

questions.q: Which pillar signifies the oneness of Allah and the prophethood of Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: The Shahada, 'La ilaha illa Allah, Muhammad rasul Allah' (There is no god but Allah, Muhammad is the messenger of Allah), is the declaration of this belief.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of Zakat?
options: To purify one's wealth and help the needy
questions.ex: Zakat serves to purify the giver's wealth and is distributed among specified categories of needy people.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a condition for performing Salat?
questions.ex: Giving charity is an important act but not a condition for the validity of Salat.

questions.q: Fasting during Ramadan is obligatory for all Muslims who are:
questions.ex: Fasting is required for adult Muslims who are healthy and not traveling or facing other valid exemptions.

questions.q: Performing Hajj is obligatory for a Muslim who:
options: Has the financial and physical ability
questions.ex: Hajj is compulsory for those who are physically and financially capable of undertaking the journey.

questions.q: The Shahada must be recited with:
options: Both the tongue and sincere belief in the heart
questions.ex: The declaration of faith must be spoken and sincerely believed in the heart.

questions.q: Which pillar emphasizes equality among Muslims by standing shoulder to shoulder?
questions.ex: Salat brings Muslims together in congregation, emphasizing equality regardless of social status.

questions.q: What is the minimum amount of wealth upon which Zakat becomes obligatory?
questions.ex: Nisab is the minimum threshold of wealth that makes Zakat obligatory.

questions.q: What is the purpose of fasting during Ramadan?
options: To gain spiritual purity and self-discipline
questions.ex: Fasting is primarily for spiritual development, self-control, and empathy for the less fortunate.

questions.q: During Hajj, pilgrims wear two seamless white sheets, which symbolize:
questions.ex: The Ihram clothing signifies a state of purity and equality among all pilgrims regardless of their worldly status.

questions.q: Which pillar directly involves financial contribution for the welfare of the community?
questions.ex: Zakat is a mandatory financial obligation aimed at redistributing wealth and helping the poor.

questions.q: What is the prescribed direction Muslims face during Salat?
questions.ex: Muslims face the Kaaba in Mecca during their prayers, which is known as the Qibla.

questions.q: Which of the following is exempted from fasting during Ramadan?
questions.ex: Travelers, the sick, pregnant or breastfeeding women, and menstruating women are among those exempted from fasting, with the requirement to make up the fast later if possible.

questions.q: Which pillar fosters a sense of unity and brotherhood among Muslims worldwide?
questions.ex: Hajj brings together Muslims from diverse backgrounds in one place, fostering a powerful sense of global Islamic unity.

questions.q: What is the minimum age for a Muslim to be obligated to perform the Five Pillars?
options: When they can read the Quran
questions.ex: The obligation to fulfill the Five Pillars generally begins upon reaching puberty, provided other conditions are met.

questions.q: Which pillar is a direct communication between the individual and Allah?
questions.ex: Salat is considered a direct communication and connection between the worshipper and Allah.

questions.q: What percentage of wealth is typically given as Zakat on eligible assets?
questions.ex: The standard rate for Zakat on most types of wealth is 2.5%.

questions.q: Breaking the fast intentionally during Ramadan without a valid reason requires:
options: Making up the missed day later
questions.ex: Intentionally breaking the fast without a valid excuse requires a kaffarah, which is a more serious form of expiation than just making up the day.

questions.q: Which of the following is a ritual performed during Hajj?
questions.ex: Tawaf, circling the Kaaba seven times, is a fundamental ritual of Hajj and Umrah.

questions.q: The concept of 'Ihsan' (excellence in worship) is most closely related to which pillar?
questions.ex: Ihsan in Salat means performing it with utmost sincerity and mindfulness, as if seeing Allah or being seen by Him.

questions.q: Zakat is distributed among specific categories of recipients mentioned in the Quran. How many such categories are there?
questions.ex: There are eight categories of people who are eligible to receive Zakat, as outlined in Surah At-Tawbah (9:60).

questions.q: What is the significance of the month of Ramadan?
options: It is the month of Eid al-Fitr
The Quran was first revealed during this month
It is the month of Hajj
It is the month of Ashura
questions.ex: Ramadan is significant because the first verses of the Holy Quran were revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) during this month.

questions.q: Besides the compulsory Hajj, Muslims can also perform a voluntary pilgrimage called:
questions.ex: Umrah is a lesser pilgrimage to Mecca that can be performed at any time of the year.

questions.q: Which pillar helps to develop empathy for the poor and needy?
questions.ex: Fasting allows individuals to experience hunger and thirst, fostering empathy and compassion for those who are less fortunate.

questions.q: What is the Arabic name for the call to prayer that precedes each Salat?
questions.ex: The Adhan is the call to prayer recited by the Muezzin.

questions.q: Which of the following is considered wealth on which Zakat is typically calculated?
questions.ex: Gold and silver that meet the Nisab are among the assets on which Zakat is calculated.

questions.q: Fasting is not just abstaining from food and drink, but also from:
questions.ex: Sawm requires abstaining from negative behavior and focusing on spiritual purification.

questions.q: The standing during Salat is known as:
questions.ex: Qiyam is the standing posture during prayer.

questions.q: Which pillar reminds Muslims of their submission and obedience to Allah?
questions.ex: The Shahada is the declaration of submission to the will of Allah.

questions.q: What is the minimum period a person must possess wealth at or above the Nisab for Zakat to be obligatory?
questions.ex: The wealth must be held for a full lunar year (Hawl) at or above the Nisab for Zakat to be due.

questions.q: Which of the following is a symbolic act performed during Hajj representing the struggle against evil?
questions.ex: Stoning the Jamarat symbolizes the rejection of temptation and evil, following the example of Prophet Ibrahim.

questions.q: In which city was Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) born?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was born in the city of Mecca in present-day Saudi Arabia.

questions.q: What was the name of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) mother?
questions.ex: The name of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) mother was Amina bint Wahb.

questions.q: At what age did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) receive his first revelation?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) received his first revelation from Allah through the Angel Jibril at the age of 40.

questions.q: In which cave did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) receive the first revelation?
questions.ex: The first revelation came to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) while he was meditating in the Cave of Hira.

questions.q: Who was the first person to accept Islam?
questions.ex: Khadijah bint Khuwaylid (RA), the Prophet's wife, was the first person to believe in his prophethood and accept Islam.

questions.q: What is the term for the migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his followers from Mecca to Medina?
questions.ex: The migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his companions from Mecca to Medina in 622 CE is known as the Hijra.

questions.q: In which year did the Hijra take place?
questions.ex: The Hijra, marking the beginning of the Islamic calendar, occurred in 622 CE.

questions.q: What was the original name of Medina?
questions.ex: Before the Hijra, Medina was known as Yathrib.

questions.q: What was the first mosque built in Islam?
questions.ex: Masjid Quba, located just outside Medina, is considered the first mosque in Islam.

questions.q: Who were the Ansar?
questions.ex: The Ansar were the local inhabitants of Medina who welcomed and supported the Muhajirun (emigrants from Mecca).

questions.q: What was the Treaty of Hudaibiyah?
options: A peace treaty between Muslims and Romans
A truce between Muslims and the Quraysh of Mecca
An alliance with the Byzantine Empire
questions.ex: The Treaty of Hudaibiyah was a significant truce signed between Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the Quraysh of Mecca in 628 CE.

questions.q: In which year did the Conquest of Mecca take place?
questions.ex: The peaceful Conquest of Mecca by the Muslims occurred in 8 AH (630 CE).

questions.q: What was the last sermon delivered by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) called?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) delivered his final sermon, known as Khutbah al-Wada' (The Farewell Sermon), during his Farewell Pilgrimage.

questions.q: In which year did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) pass away?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) passed away in Medina in 10 AH (632 CE).

questions.q: What was the name of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) first wife?
questions.ex: Khadijah bint Khuwaylid (RA) was the first wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: How many daughters did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) have with Khadijah (RA)?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and Khadijah (RA) had four daughters: Zainab, Ruqayyah, Umm Kulthum, and Fatimah.

questions.q: Who was the paternal uncle of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) who protected him?
questions.ex: Abu Talib, the paternal uncle of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), provided him with protection in Mecca.

questions.q: What is the Night Journey of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) known as?
questions.ex: The miraculous journey of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Jerusalem and then to the heavens is known as Isra and Mi'raj.

questions.q: What was the main message of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) prophethood?
questions.ex: The central message of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) prophethood was the belief in the absolute oneness of Allah (Tawhid).

questions.q: Which battle was the first major military engagement between the Muslims and the Quraysh of Mecca?
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr in 624 CE was the first significant battle between the early Muslims and the Quraysh.

questions.q: In which battle were the Muslims initially victorious but later suffered losses?
questions.ex: In the Battle of Uhud (625 CE), the Muslims faced setbacks after initial success.

questions.q: What was the primary strategy of the Muslims in the Battle of Khandaq (Trench)?
questions.ex: In the Battle of Khandaq (Trench) in 627 CE, the Muslims dug a trench around Medina to defend against the attacking forces.

questions.q: What was the role of the Muhajirun?
options: Those who migrated from Mecca to Medina
questions.ex: The Muhajirun were the early Muslims who emigrated from Mecca to Medina to escape persecution.

questions.q: What is the significance of the year of grief ('Am al-Huzn)?
options: The year of the first battle
The year when Prophet Muhammad's uncle and wife passed away
The year of the Conquest of Mecca
questions.ex: The year of grief ('Am al-Huzn) was the year when Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) lost his beloved wife Khadijah (RA) and his protective uncle Abu Talib.

questions.q: Who accompanied Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) on the Hijra to Medina?
questions.ex: Abu Bakr al-Siddiq (RA) accompanied Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) during the Hijra.

questions.q: What was the Charter of Medina?
options: A document establishing a multi-religious state in Medina
A treaty with the Byzantine Empire
questions.ex: The Charter of Medina was a foundational document that regulated relations between the different communities in Medina after the Hijra, creating a form of multi-religious state.

questions.q: How long did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) live in Medina after the Hijra?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) lived in Medina for approximately 10 years after the Hijra until his passing.

questions.q: What is the Sunnah of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
options: The sayings and actions of the Prophet
questions.ex: The Sunnah refers to the practices, sayings, and silent approvals of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), serving as a model for Muslims.

questions.q: What was the name of the first mosque built in Medina by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Masjid al-Nabawi (The Prophet's Mosque) was built in Medina after the Hijra and became a central place for the Muslim community.

questions.q: What was the main reason for the Battle of Badr?
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr was a culmination of various factors, including religious differences, control of trade routes, and the Quraysh's desire for revenge.

questions.q: Who was the main opponent of the Muslims in the early battles?
questions.ex: The primary opponents of the early Muslims in Mecca and the initial battles were the Quraysh tribe.

questions.q: What is the significance of the Farewell Pilgrimage?
options: It was the first pilgrimage for Muslims
Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) delivered his final sermon
It marked the end of the battles
It was the only pilgrimage performed by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)
questions.ex: The Farewell Pilgrimage is significant because Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) delivered his comprehensive final sermon during this pilgrimage.

questions.q: What was the age of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) when he passed away?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) passed away at the age of 63.

questions.q: Where was Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) buried?
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was buried in Medina, in Masjid al-Nabawi.

questions.q: Who was the first male to accept Islam?
questions.ex: Abu Bakr al-Siddiq (RA) was the first free adult male to accept Islam.

questions.q: What was the name of Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) wet nurse?
questions.ex: Halimah al-Sa'diyah was the wet nurse of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: What is the event of the splitting of the moon called?
questions.ex: The miracle of the splitting of the moon is known as Shaqq al-Qamar.

questions.q: What was the first Qibla (direction of prayer) in Islam?
questions.ex: Initially, the Qibla for Muslims was Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem).

questions.q: To where was the Qibla changed?
questions.ex: The Qibla was later changed to the Kaaba in Mecca by the command of Allah.

questions.q: What is the name of the treaty that allowed Muslims to perform Umrah the following year?
questions.ex: The Treaty of Hudaibiyah included a clause allowing the Muslims to perform Umrah (minor pilgrimage) the following year.

questions.q: What is the Arabic term for the biography or life story of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Seerah is the traditional Arabic term for the biography or life story of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Before his prophethood, Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was known for his:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was renowned for his honesty and reliability, earning the title 'Al-Amin' (The Trustworthy).

questions.q: The first revelation to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) occurred in:
questions.ex: The first revelation of the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) took place in the Cave of Hira near Mecca.

questions.q: The migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his followers from Mecca to Medina is known as:
questions.ex: The Hijrah was the migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his companions from Mecca to Medina in 622 CE, marking the beginning of the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: The treaty signed between the Muslims of Medina and the Jews, Christians, and pagans living there was called the:
questions.ex: The Constitution of Medina (Sahifat al-Madinah) was a document that regulated relations among the different communities in Medina.

questions.q: The first major battle between the Muslims and the Meccan polytheists was the Battle of:
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr in 624 CE was the first significant military encounter between the early Muslims and the Meccan forces.

questions.q: During the Battle of Uhud, the Muslim archers disobeyed the Prophet's orders, leading to a setback. This highlights the importance of:
questions.ex: The outcome of the Battle of Uhud emphasized the critical importance of obedience to the instructions of the Prophet (PBUH).

questions.q: The Battle of Khandaq (Trench) is also known as the Battle of:
questions.ex: The Battle of Khandaq is called the Battle of the Confederates because various tribes allied against the Muslims.

questions.q: The Treaty of Hudaibiyah was a significant agreement between the Muslims and the Meccans that paved the way for:
questions.ex: Despite initial Muslim reservations, the Treaty of Hudaibiyah established a ten-year truce and allowed for peaceful interactions, ultimately benefiting the spread of Islam.

questions.q: The conquest of Mecca by the Muslims occurred in which year AH (After Hijrah)?
questions.ex: Mecca was peacefully conquered by the Muslims in the 8th year after the Hijrah (630 CE).

questions.q: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) delivered his Farewell Sermon during his last Hajj. This sermon emphasized:
options: Equality, justice, and the rights of others
questions.ex: The Farewell Sermon is a cornerstone of Islamic teachings, emphasizing universal principles of equality, justice, and human rights.

questions.q: The companions of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) are known as:
questions.ex: Sahaba are the companions who saw or met Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and believed in him.

questions.q: Those who migrated from Mecca to Medina with Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) were called:
questions.ex: Muhajireen were the early Muslims who migrated from Mecca to Medina.

questions.q: The residents of Medina who welcomed and supported the Muhajireen were called:
questions.ex: Ansar were the helpers, the residents of Medina who aided the Muslim migrants from Mecca.

questions.q: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is considered a mercy to all creation, as mentioned in the Quran. This signifies the __________ nature of his message.
questions.ex: The Quran describes Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) as a mercy to all worlds, indicating the universal scope of Islam.

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) strongly discouraged tribalism and emphasized the importance of unity based on:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) broke down tribal barriers and united people under the banner of Tawhid (Oneness of God).

questions.q: The practice and teachings of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) are collectively known as the:
questions.ex: Sunnah refers to the practices, sayings, and approvals of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The sayings and actions of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) recorded by his companions are called:
questions.ex: Hadith are the narrations reporting the sayings and actions of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: One of the key characteristics of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)'s leadership was his:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) frequently consulted with his companions on important matters, demonstrating the principle of Shura.

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) emphasized the importance of seeking knowledge, stating it is a duty upon every:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) stressed that seeking knowledge is obligatory for all Muslims, regardless of gender.

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) taught that the best among you is the one who is best to his:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) emphasized the importance of treating one's family with kindness and respect.

questions.q: Before the advent of Islam, the period in Arabia was known as:
questions.ex: The pre-Islamic era in Arabia is referred to as Jahiliyyah, characterized by idol worship, tribal conflicts, and social injustice.

questions.q: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was born in the Year of the Elephant. This year is significant because of an event involving the:
options: Arrival of a large army with elephants to destroy the Kaaba
Discovery of a new trade route
Migration of a large bird species
questions.ex: The Year of the Elephant refers to the year Abraha, the Abyssinian ruler of Yemen, attempted to attack the Kaaba with an army that included elephants.

questions.q: The foster mother of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was:
questions.ex: Halimah al-Sa'diyah was the Bedouin woman who nursed and raised Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) in his early years.

questions.q: The first wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was:
questions.ex: Khadeeja bint Khuwaylid was the first wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and a significant support during the early days of Islam.

questions.q: The cave where Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) received the first revelation is:
questions.ex: The Cave of Hira is located near Mecca and is where Angel Jibril (Gabriel) first revealed verses of the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The event of Isra and Mi'raj refers to the Prophet's miraculous journey to:
options: Jerusalem and then to the heavens
questions.ex: Isra and Mi'raj describe Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) night journey from Mecca to Jerusalem and his subsequent ascent to the heavens.

questions.q: The main reason for the Meccan opposition to Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) message was that it threatened their:

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) taught that cleanliness is half of:

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) dealt with his enemies and those who harmed him with:

questions.q: The Prophet (PBUH) is considered the last prophet in a chain of prophets sent by Allah. This belief is known as:

subcategories.title: The Holy Quran (Revelation, Compilation, Surahs, Verses)

questions.q: Through which angel was the Holy Quran revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: The Holy Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) through the Angel Jibreel (Gabriel).

questions.q: How long did the revelation of the Holy Quran take?
questions.ex: The revelation of the Holy Quran took approximately 23 years, from 610 CE to 632 CE.

questions.q: What is the first Surah of the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: Al-Fatiha is the first Surah of the Holy Quran and is known as the 'Opening'.

questions.q: How many Surahs are there in the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: There are 114 Surahs (chapters) in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: Which is the longest Surah in the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: Surah Al-Baqarah (The Cow) is the longest Surah in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: During which period was the Holy Quran primarily compiled into a single volume?
options: During the lifetime of the Prophet (PBUH)
During the time of Hazrat Abu Bakr (RA)
During the time of Hazrat Umar (RA)
During the time of Hazrat Uthman (RA)
questions.ex: The definitive compilation of the Holy Quran into a single mushaf (volume) occurred during the caliphate of Hazrat Uthman (RA).

questions.q: What is the name given to the verses of the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: The individual verses of the Holy Quran are called Ayat (signs or verses).

questions.q: Where was the first revelation of the Holy Quran received?
questions.ex: The first revelation of the Holy Quran was received by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) in the Cave of Hira, near Mecca.

questions.q: What does 'Makki' Surah refer to?
questions.ex: Makki Surahs are those that were revealed in Mecca before the Hijra (migration) to Medina.

questions.q: What does 'Madani' Surah refer to?
questions.ex: Madani Surahs are those that were revealed in Medina after the Hijra.

questions.q: What is the primary language of the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: The Holy Quran was revealed in the Arabic language.

questions.q: Who was primarily responsible for the final compilation of the Holy Quran during Hazrat Uthman's (RA) time?
questions.ex: Zayd ibn Thabit (RA) was a key scribe of the Prophet (PBUH) and played a central role in the compilation of the Quran during Hazrat Uthman's (RA) caliphate.

questions.q: What is the significance of Laylat al-Qadr?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr (The Night of Power or Decree) is the night when the first verses of the Holy Quran were revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which Surah is often referred to as the 'Heart of the Quran'?
questions.ex: Surah Ya-Sin is commonly referred to as the 'Heart of the Quran'.

questions.q: How many parts (Juz) is the Holy Quran divided into?
questions.ex: The Holy Quran is divided into 30 parts (Juz) for ease of recitation.

questions.q: What does 'Tajweed' refer to?
options: Rules of reciting the Quran correctly
questions.ex: Tajweed refers to the set of rules governing the correct pronunciation of the letters with all their qualities and applying the various rules of recitation.

questions.q: What is the meaning of 'Tafsir'?
options: Explanation or interpretation of the Quran
questions.ex: Tafsir is the explanation or interpretation of the Holy Quran.

questions.q: Which Surah is known as the 'Mother of the Book'?
questions.ex: Surah Al-Fatiha is often called 'Umm al-Kitab' (Mother of the Book).

questions.q: How were the initial revelations of the Quran preserved before its compilation?
options: They were written on various materials like animal skins and leaves
They were stored on clay tablets
questions.ex: The revelations were initially preserved through memorization by companions and by being written down on various available materials.

questions.q: What is the primary theme of Makki Surahs?
options: Oneness of Allah, prophethood, and the hereafter
questions.ex: Makki Surahs primarily focus on the fundamental beliefs of Islam: the Oneness of Allah (Tawhid), prophethood (Risalah), and the concept of the hereafter (Akhirah).

questions.q: What is the primary theme of Madani Surahs?
options: Oneness of Allah and the hereafter
Islamic law, social life, and state matters
questions.ex: Madani Surahs often deal with Islamic law, social organization, community building, and guidelines for the nascent Islamic state.

questions.q: What is the meaning of the word 'Quran'?
questions.ex: The word 'Quran' literally means 'the reading' or 'the recitation'.

questions.q: Which event marked the beginning of the revelation of the Holy Quran?
options: The first visit of Jibreel (AS) to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) in the Cave of Hira
questions.ex: The revelation of the Quran began with the first visit of Angel Jibreel (AS) to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) in the Cave of Hira.

questions.q: What is the significance of the arrangement of Surahs in the Holy Quran?
options: They are arranged chronologically by revelation
The arrangement was guided by divine instruction
They are arranged by length, shortest first
questions.ex: The order and arrangement of the Surahs in the Quran is considered to be divinely ordained (Tawqifi).

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a name for the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: Al-Furqan (The Criterion), Al-Kitab (The Book), and Al-Nur (The Light) are names for the Holy Quran. Al-Sunnah refers to the practices and teachings of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: What is the number of verses in the Holy Quran (approximately)?
questions.ex: The exact number of verses varies slightly depending on the method of counting, but it is generally considered to be over 6000 (around 6236 or more).

questions.q: Who was the scribe who wrote down the initial revelations for Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Zayd ibn Thabit (RA) was one of the main scribes who wrote down the Quranic revelations during the Prophet's lifetime.

questions.q: What is the meaning of 'Ayat al-Kursi'?
questions.ex: Ayat al-Kursi is known as the 'Verse of the Throne' and is the 255th verse of Surah Al-Baqarah.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the Holy Quran?
options: To tell stories of past nations
To provide guidance for all aspects of human life
To serve as a historical record
questions.ex: The Holy Quran serves as a complete guide for all aspects of human life, providing principles for faith, worship, morality, and social interactions.

questions.q: What does 'Mushaf' refer to?
options: A person who has memorized the Quran
A written copy of the Holy Quran
questions.ex: Mushaf refers to a written copy of the Holy Quran.

questions.q: Which Surah is recited in every Rakat of Salah (prayer)?
questions.ex: Surah Al-Fatiha is mandatory to recite in every Rakat of Salah.

questions.q: What is the name of the science dealing with the proper recitation of the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: Tajweed is the science that deals with the correct pronunciation and recitation of the Holy Quran.

questions.q: During whose caliphate was the standardization of the Quranic text carried out?
questions.ex: The standardization of the Quranic text to prevent variations occurred during the caliphate of Hazrat Uthman (RA).

questions.q: What does 'Asbab al-Nuzul' refer to?
options: The order of Surahs in the Quran
The circumstances and reasons for the revelation of specific Quranic verses
The different readings of the Quran
The grammar of the Arabic language in the Quran
questions.ex: Asbab al-Nuzul refers to the circumstances and reasons behind the revelation of particular Quranic verses or Surahs.

questions.q: Which of the following best describes the style of the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: The style of the Holy Quran is considered unique and inimitable, challenging both poets and linguists of the time.

questions.q: What is the main message of the Holy Quran?
options: The laws of trade and commerce
The Oneness of Allah and the path to guidance
questions.ex: The central message of the Holy Quran is the absolute Oneness of Allah (Tawhid) and providing guidance for humanity to live a righteous life.

questions.q: How many times is the name 'Allah' mentioned in the Holy Quran (approximately)?
questions.ex: The name 'Allah' is mentioned approximately 2700 times in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: What is the literal meaning of the word 'Hadith'?
questions.ex: Literally, Hadith means saying, report, or communication.

questions.q: The Sunnah refers to the practices, traditions, and way of life of:
questions.ex: Sunnah specifically refers to the way of life of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which of the following is considered a primary source of Islamic law after the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: Hadith and Sunnah are considered the second primary source of Islamic law after the Quran.

questions.q: A Hadith consists of two main parts: the Sanad (chain of narrators) and the:
questions.ex: A Hadith is composed of the Sanad (chain of narrators) and the Matn (the text of the Hadith).

questions.q: Which famous collection of Hadith is considered one of the most authentic?
questions.ex: Sahih Bukhari is widely regarded as one of the most authentic collections of Hadith.

questions.q: Hadith Qudsi are sayings of:
questions.ex: Hadith Qudsi are sayings of Allah transmitted through Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The process of critically examining the chain of narrators of a Hadith is called:
questions.ex: Ilm al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil is the science of evaluating the reliability of Hadith narrators.

questions.q: Which type of Hadith is considered the strongest in authenticity?
questions.ex: Sahih Hadith are considered the most authentic and reliable.

questions.q: The Sunnah can be categorized into three types: Sunnah Qauliyyah (sayings), Sunnah Fi'liyyah (actions), and Sunnah:
questions.ex: The three types of Sunnah are Qauliyyah, Fi'liyyah, and Taqririyyah (silent approvals).

questions.q: Who is considered the most prominent compiler of Sahih Hadith?
questions.ex: Imam Muhammad al-Bukhari is renowned for his Sahih al-Bukhari.

questions.q: A Hadith is classified as 'Dha'if' if it is:
options: Good but not as strong as Sahih
questions.ex: A Dha'if Hadith is one with a weakness in its chain of narration or text, making it unreliable.

questions.q: The collection of Hadith compiled by Imam Muslim is known as:
questions.ex: Sahih Muslim is the collection of Hadith compiled by Imam Muslim.

questions.q: What is the purpose of studying Hadith?
options: To follow the example of the Prophet (PBUH)
questions.ex: Studying Hadith helps in understanding the Quran, following the Prophet's example, and deriving Islamic rulings.

questions.q: The term 'Mutawatir' Hadith refers to a Hadith narrated by:
options: A large number of narrators from different chains
questions.ex: A Mutawatir Hadith is transmitted by such a large number of narrators in each generation that it is impossible for them to have conspired to fabricate it.

questions.q: Which of the following is not one of the Kutub al-Sittah (Six Major Hadith Collections)?
questions.ex: Muwatta Imam Malik is an important early collection, but it is not one of the traditionally recognized Kutub al-Sittah.

questions.q: The science that deals with the interpretation and understanding of Hadith is called:
questions.ex: Ilm Usul al-Hadith (Science of Hadith Principles) deals with the methodology of Hadith evaluation and understanding.

questions.q: What does 'Sanad' in a Hadith refer to?
options: The ruling derived from the Hadith
questions.ex: The Sanad is the chain of individuals who transmitted the Hadith from the Prophet (PBUH) down to the compiler.

questions.q: A Hadith classified as 'Hasan' is considered:
questions.ex: A Hasan Hadith is good and acceptable, though its chain of narration might not be as strong as a Sahih Hadith.

questions.q: The compilation of Hadith started formally during the time of the:
questions.ex: Formal compilation of Hadith began during the time of the Prophet (PBUH), with some companions recording Hadith.

questions.q: What is the primary reason for the rigorous process of Hadith authentication?
options: To count the number of Hadith
To ensure their authenticity and reliability
questions.ex: The rigorous authentication process was vital to ensure the accuracy and reliability of Hadith as a source of Islamic guidance.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of Sunnah Fi'liyyah?
options: The Prophet's actions in performing prayer
The Prophet's approval of an action done by a companion
questions.ex: Sunnah Fi'liyyah refers to the actions of the Prophet (PBUH), such as how he performed his prayers.

questions.q: A Hadith that is fabricated and falsely attributed to the Prophet (PBUH) is called:
questions.ex: A Maudu' Hadith is a fabricated or forged Hadith.

questions.q: The six major collections of Hadith (Kutub al-Sittah) were compiled by scholars in the:
questions.ex: The Kutub al-Sittah were primarily compiled during the 2nd and 3rd centuries of Hijri.

questions.q: What does 'Matn' in a Hadith refer to?
options: The text or content of the Hadith
questions.ex: The Matn is the actual text of the Hadith, containing the saying, action, or approval of the Prophet (PBUH).

questions.q: The Sunnah serves as a practical explanation and elaboration of the:
questions.ex: The Sunnah explains and elaborates on the general principles and commands found in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: The term 'Muhaddith' refers to a scholar who specializes in:
questions.ex: A Muhaddith is a scholar of Hadith who has extensive knowledge and expertise in the field.

questions.q: A Hadith classified as 'Marfu'' is one that is directly attributed to:
questions.ex: A Marfu' Hadith is one whose chain of narration reaches back directly to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The process of recording and preserving Hadith is known as:
questions.ex: Tadwin al-Hadith refers to the process of compiling and writing down Hadith.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of Sunnah Taqririyyah?
options: The Prophet's silence regarding an action done by a companion, implying approval
questions.ex: Sunnah Taqririyyah is the Prophet's silent approval of an action or saying by a companion.

questions.q: The term 'Isnad' is synonymous with:
questions.ex: Isnad is another term used to refer to the Sanad or the chain of narrators.

questions.q: A Hadith that is not attributed directly to the Prophet (PBUH) but to a Sahabi is called:
questions.ex: A Mawquf Hadith is one whose chain of narration stops at a Sahabi (companion).

questions.q: The six major collections of Hadith are also collectively known as:
questions.ex: The six major collections are collectively known as Al-Kutub al-Sittah.

questions.q: Which of the following is a benefit of following the Sunnah?
questions.ex: Following the Sunnah helps in achieving closeness to Allah, understanding the Quran, and leading a balanced life in accordance with Islamic teachings.

questions.q: The science of Hadith criticism aims to:
options: Evaluate the authenticity and reliability of Hadith
questions.ex: Hadith criticism focuses on assessing the genuineness and trustworthiness of Hadith reports.

questions.q: A narrator of Hadith is called a:
questions.ex: A Rawi is a person who narrates a Hadith.

questions.q: Who was the first Rightly Guided Caliph?
questions.ex: Abu Bakr al-Siddiq was the first Caliph after the passing of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which Caliph is known for the expansion of the Islamic empire and the establishment of administrative systems?
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab is renowned for his administrative skills and the significant expansion of the Islamic state.

questions.q: The compilation and standardization of the Holy Quran is primarily attributed to the time of which Caliph?
questions.ex: During the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan, a standardized version of the Quran was compiled and distributed.

questions.q: Which Caliph was a cousin and son-in-law of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Ali ibn Abi Talib was the cousin and son-in-law of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The Ridda Wars (Wars of Apostasy) took place during the caliphate of which Rightly Guided Caliph?
questions.ex: The Ridda Wars were fought during the caliphate of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq to bring various Arabian tribes back into the fold of Islam.

questions.q: Which Caliph was known for his justice and fairness, often referred to as 'Al-Farooq' (the Discerner)?
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab was given the title 'Al-Farooq' due to his keen sense of justice and his ability to discern truth from falsehood.

questions.q: The third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan, belonged to which tribe?
questions.ex: Uthman ibn Affan belonged to the Banu Umayya tribe.

questions.q: Which Caliph moved the capital of the Islamic empire to Kufa?
questions.ex: Ali ibn Abi Talib moved the capital of the Islamic empire from Medina to Kufa.

questions.q: The system of 'Diwan' (register of soldiers and their stipends) was introduced during the caliphate of which leader?
questions.ex: The system of Diwan was established by Umar ibn al-Khattab to organize the administration and finances of the expanding empire.

questions.q: Which Caliph was known for his generosity and was titled 'Dhul-Noorayn' (possessor of two lights) for marrying two daughters of the Prophet (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Uthman ibn Affan was called 'Dhul-Noorayn' because he married Ruqayyah and Umm Kulthum, both daughters of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The battle of Yarmouk, a significant victory against the Byzantine Empire, occurred during the caliphate of:
questions.ex: The Battle of Yarmouk, a decisive victory for the Muslims, took place during the reign of Umar ibn al-Khattab.

questions.q: Who was the last of the Rightly Guided Caliphs?
questions.ex: Ali ibn Abi Talib was the fourth and last of the Rightly Guided Caliphs.

questions.q: The concept of 'Shura' (consultation) was a key principle followed by the Rightly Guided Caliphs. Who emphasized this the most in his administration?
questions.ex: All the Rightly Guided Caliphs practiced Shura, but Umar ibn al-Khattab is particularly noted for establishing a formal system of consultation.

questions.q: Which Caliph faced significant internal dissent and conflict during his rule?
questions.ex: Both Uthman ibn Affan and Ali ibn Abi Talib faced significant internal conflicts and challenges during their caliphates.

questions.q: The system of provinces and the appointment of governors were further developed under which Caliph?
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab structured the growing Islamic state into provinces with appointed governors to maintain order and administration.

questions.q: Who was the first person to accept Islam publicly after Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Abu Bakr al-Siddiq was among the very first to accept Islam and was a close companion of the Prophet (PBUH).

questions.q: Which Caliph was known for his piety and devotion to Islam, spending much of his wealth for the cause of Islam?
questions.ex: Uthman ibn Affan was renowned for his immense generosity and his significant financial contributions to support the Muslim community and its expansion.

questions.q: The Battle of the Camel and the Battle of Siffin were major conflicts during the caliphate of:

questions.q: Which Caliph established the Islamic calendar (Hijri calendar)?

questions.q: The title 'Al-Siddiq' (The Truthful) was given to which Caliph?
questions.ex: Abu Bakr was given the title 'Al-Siddiq' due to his unwavering belief and support for Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The system of 'Bayt al-Mal' (Public Treasury) was formally organized during the reign of:
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab organized and expanded the Bayt al-Mal to manage the state's finances effectively.

questions.q: Which Caliph is buried alongside Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and Abu Bakr (RA) in Medina?
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab is buried in the Prophet's Mosque in Medina, next to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and Abu Bakr (RA).

questions.q: The expansion into Persia and parts of the Byzantine Empire reached its peak during the caliphate of:
questions.ex: The Islamic empire saw significant territorial expansion under the leadership of Umar ibn al-Khattab.

questions.q: Which Caliph is known for his wisdom, knowledge, and eloquent speeches?
questions.ex: Ali ibn Abi Talib was renowned for his profound knowledge, wisdom, and eloquence.

questions.q: The period of the Rightly Guided Caliphs is considered a golden age of Islamic rule because of their adherence to:
questions.ex: The Rightly Guided Caliphs are revered for their just rule and their commitment to the principles and teachings of Islam.

questions.q: Which Caliph faced the first major organized opposition and rebellion within the Muslim community?
questions.ex: Uthman ibn Affan's later years of caliphate were marked by increasing dissent and ultimately led to rebellion.

questions.q: The system of assigning pensions to the needy and disabled was introduced by which Caliph?
questions.ex: Umar ibn al-Khattab established a system of social welfare, including pensions for those in need.

questions.q: Who was assassinated while leading the Fajr prayer?

questions.q: Which Caliph was known for his humility and simple lifestyle despite the vastness of the empire he ruled?

questions.q: Who was the Muslim general who conquered Egypt in the 7th century?

questions.q: The Mughal Empire was established in which subcontinent?

questions.q: Which famous Muslim philosopher is known in the West as Avicenna?

questions.q: Which Islamic empire is known for its significant naval power in the Mediterranean?

questions.q: The Umayyad Caliphate had its capital in which city?

questions.q: The Battle of Mut'ah was fought against which empire?

questions.q: Who was the commander of the Muslim army at the Battle of Yarmouk?

questions.q: The Battle of Qadisiyyah was a decisive battle against which empire?

questions.q: Which battle led to the opening of Egypt to Muslim rule?

questions.q: The Battle of Nehawand is known as the 'Victory of Victories' against which empire?
questions.ex: The Battle of Nehawand was another crucial victory for the Muslims against the Sasanian Empire.

questions.q: In which battle did the Muslims face a significantly larger army but emerged victorious due to divine assistance?

questions.q: Which battle is known for the miraculous intervention that helped the Muslims?

questions.q: Which battle involved a prolonged siege where the Muslims faced harsh conditions?

questions.q: The Battle of Mu'tah is significant because it was the first major clash between Muslims and which empire?
questions.ex: The Battle of Mu'tah marked the first significant military engagement between the nascent Muslim state and the powerful Byzantine Empire.

questions.q: Who took command of the Muslim army in the Battle of Mu'tah after the initial commanders were martyred?
questions.ex: Khalid ibn al-Walid took command and skillfully managed the Muslim retreat after the martyrdom of the appointed commanders.

questions.q: The Battle of Nahrawan was fought against which group?

questions.q: What was the primary outcome of the Battle of Khandaq for the Muslims?

questions.q: What was the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate during its Golden Age?

questions.q: Which prominent Muslim scholar is considered the 'Father of Algebra'?
questions.ex: Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi was a Persian mathematician and astronomer whose work laid the foundations for algebra.

questions.q: The Great Mosque of Cordoba is a famous example of architecture from which Islamic dynasty?
questions.ex: The Great Mosque of Cordoba in Spain was built by the Umayyad rulers of Al-Andalus.

questions.q: What is the term for the traditional Islamic art of beautiful handwriting?
questions.ex: Calligraphy is the art of beautiful handwriting and holds a significant place in Islamic art due to the importance of the Quran.

questions.q: Which city was a major center of learning and translation during the Abbasid period, housing the 'House of Wisdom'?
questions.ex: Baghdad's 'House of Wisdom' was a renowned intellectual center during the Abbasid Golden Age, facilitating the translation of numerous works.

questions.q: What was the primary language of scholarship and administration in the Islamic world during the medieval period?
questions.ex: Arabic was the language of the Quran and became the lingua franca of the Islamic world for scholarship, science, and administration.

questions.q: Which branch of science saw significant advancements in the Islamic world, leading to the development of astronomical tables and observatories?
questions.ex: Muslim scholars made significant contributions to astronomy, establishing observatories and developing accurate astronomical tables.

questions.q: The architectural style characterized by pointed arches, domes, and minarets is commonly associated with:
questions.ex: Islamic architecture is characterized by distinctive features like pointed arches, domes, and minarets.

questions.q: What was the role of the 'Bazaar' in Islamic cities?

questions.q: Which famous Muslim traveler is known for his extensive journeys across the Islamic world and beyond in the 14th century?

questions.q: The concept of 'Adab' in Islamic culture refers to:
questions.ex: Adab encompasses proper etiquette, good manners, and refined behavior in Islamic culture.

questions.q: Which art form in Islamic culture often features intricate geometric patterns and floral designs, avoiding human or animal figures?
questions.ex: Islamic art frequently uses geometric patterns and floral designs (arabesque) in mosaics and other decorative arts, often due to interpretations of religious guidelines regarding figural representation.

questions.q: What was the significance of the city of Timbuktu during the Mali Empire?
options: A renowned center of Islamic learning and trade
questions.ex: Timbuktu was a flourishing center of Islamic scholarship, trade, and culture during the Mali Empire in West Africa.

questions.q: The development of hospitals and the practice of surgery saw significant advancements in which period of Islamic history?
questions.ex: The Abbasid Golden Age saw significant progress in medicine, including the establishment of hospitals and advancements in surgery.

questions.q: What is the name of the traditional Islamic garden style, often featuring fountains and geometric layouts?
questions.ex: Persian gardens, with their emphasis on water features, shade, and geometric patterns, significantly influenced Islamic garden design.

questions.q: Which musical instrument is considered iconic in Islamic music and culture?
questions.ex: The Oud is a stringed instrument widely used in traditional Arabic and Islamic music.

questions.q: The concept of 'Waqf' in Islamic civilization refers to:
questions.ex: Waqf is an Islamic endowment of property to be held in trust and used for charitable or religious purposes.

questions.q: Which famous philosopher from Al-Andalus (Islamic Spain) was known for his commentaries on Aristotle?
questions.ex: Ibn Rushd, also known as Averroes, was a prominent philosopher and commentator on Aristotle from Islamic Spain.

questions.q: What was the primary purpose of the 'Madrasa' in Islamic civilization?
questions.ex: A Madrasa is an Islamic educational institution, traditionally for the study of religious sciences but often including other subjects.

questions.q: The art of book illumination and miniature painting flourished in which Islamic empires?
questions.ex: Book illumination and miniature painting were particularly prominent in the Mughal and Safavid empires.

questions.q: Which invention from the Islamic world had a significant impact on navigation?
questions.ex: While the compass was known in China earlier, Muslim scholars and sailors played a significant role in its widespread adoption and improvement in the maritime world.

questions.q: The tradition of storytelling and oral poetry was a significant part of culture in which region before and during the rise of Islam?
questions.ex: Oral poetry and storytelling were deeply ingrained in the culture of the Arabian Peninsula before and during the early Islamic period.

questions.q: Which city is considered a major center of Islamic art and architecture in present-day Uzbekistan, known for its mosques and madrasas?
questions.ex: Bukhara is a historic city in Uzbekistan renowned for its impressive Islamic architecture, including numerous mosques and madrasas.

questions.q: The development of complex water management systems, such as Qanats, was a notable achievement in Islamic civilization, particularly in which region?
questions.ex: Qanats, underground water channels, were extensively developed and used for irrigation in the arid regions of the Middle East and North Africa during the Islamic era.

questions.q: What is the name of the distinctive pointed arch often used in Islamic architecture?
questions.ex: The horseshoe arch is a distinctive feature commonly found in Islamic architecture, particularly in North Africa and Spain.

questions.q: The concept of 'Zakat' is not only a religious obligation but also had implications for the economic and social structure of early Islamic society, primarily as a form of:
questions.ex: Zakat is a mandatory charitable contribution that served as a system of wealth distribution and social welfare in early Islamic society.

questions.q: Which field of study was advanced by Muslim scholars through the translation and preservation of ancient Greek texts?
questions.ex: Muslim scholars played a crucial role in preserving and translating ancient Greek texts, significantly advancing the fields of medicine and philosophy.

questions.q: The use of geometric patterns in Islamic art is often interpreted as a reflection of the belief in:
questions.ex: The intricate and often infinite nature of geometric patterns in Islamic art is seen as a reflection of the divine unity (Tawhid) and the order of the universe.

questions.q: Which significant library and center of learning existed in Islamic Spain (Al-Andalus)?
questions.ex: The Library of Cordoba in Al-Andalus was a famous and extensive library during the Islamic golden age.

questions.q: The development of paper manufacturing and its spread from the East to the West was significantly influenced by:
questions.ex: The technology of paper manufacturing was introduced to the Islamic world from China and subsequently spread to Europe through Muslim lands.

questions.q: Which form of performing art, often involving music and dance, has a rich history in Islamic cultures, particularly in Sufi traditions?
questions.ex: The Whirling Dervishes are a prominent example of a spiritual performing art form associated with Sufism.

questions.q: What was the main purpose of the caravanserais built across the Islamic world?
questions.ex: Caravanserais were roadside inns built to provide lodging and facilities for travelers and merchants along trade routes.

questions.q: The concept of 'Ijma' in Islamic jurisprudence refers to:
questions.ex: Ijma is the consensus of Muslim scholars on a point of Islamic law, considered a source of legislation.

questions.q: Which city in the Islamic world was renowned for its production of textiles, particularly silk?
questions.ex: Isfahan in Persia (Iran) was historically famous for its exquisite silk textiles.

questions.q: The development of the astrolabe, a sophisticated astronomical instrument, was a significant contribution of scholars from which civilization?
questions.ex: Muslim scholars significantly improved and popularized the astrolabe, making it an essential tool for astronomy and navigation.

questions.q: Which form of literature is highly valued in Islamic culture, often used to express religious devotion and moral lessons?
questions.ex: Poetry has a long and rich tradition in Islamic culture and is often used for religious, philosophical, and expressive purposes.

questions.q: The concept of 'Bayt al-Mal' in early Islamic history refers to:
questions.ex: Bayt al-Mal was the public treasury in early Islamic states, responsible for managing state revenue and expenditure.

questions.q: Which industry saw advancements in the Islamic world through the development of new techniques and materials, such as glazed tiles?
questions.ex: Islamic civilization saw significant developments in pottery and ceramics, including the widespread use of glazed tiles for decoration.

questions.q: The concept of 'Urf' in Islamic law refers to:
questions.ex: 'Urf' refers to the recognized customs and traditions of a community, which can be considered in Islamic law provided they do not contradict Islamic principles.

questions.q: Which architectural element, often found in mosques, is used for calling Muslims to prayer?
questions.ex: The minaret is a tower from which the muezzin calls the faithful to prayer (adhan).

questions.q: What is the primary source of Islamic law (Shariah)?
questions.ex: The Quran is considered the ultimate source of Islamic law, as it contains the direct words of Allah.

questions.q: Which of the following is a secondary source of Islamic law, comprising the sayings and actions of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Hadith are the narrations about the sayings, actions, and approvals of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and serve as a crucial source of Islamic law.

questions.q: What is Ijma in the context of Islamic law?
questions.ex: Ijma refers to the consensus of qualified Islamic scholars on a matter of religious law.

questions.q: Which source of Islamic law involves analogical reasoning to derive a ruling for a new situation based on a similar case found in the Quran or Sunnah?
questions.ex: Qiyas is the process of analogical deduction, where a ruling for a new case is derived by comparing it to a similar case with a known ruling in the primary sources.

questions.q: What does the term 'Shariah' literally mean?
options: The path to the water source
questions.ex: The word 'Shariah' literally translates to 'the path to the water source,' symbolizing the clear path to guidance and life.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT considered a primary objective (Maqasid al-Shariah) of Islamic law?
questions.ex: The primary objectives of Shariah include the protection of religion, life, intellect, progeny, and wealth. Entertainment is not a primary objective.

questions.q: What is the term for independent reasoning or interpretation of Islamic law by a qualified scholar?
questions.ex: Ijtihad is the effort a qualified scholar makes to derive or interpret a rule of Islamic law from the primary sources.

questions.q: Which school of thought in Islamic jurisprudence is named after Imam Abu Hanifa?
questions.ex: The Hanafi school of thought is one of the four major Sunni schools of Islamic jurisprudence and is named after its founder, Imam Abu Hanifa.

questions.q: What does the term 'Halal' signify in Islamic law?
questions.ex: Halal refers to actions or things that are permissible or lawful according to Islamic law.

questions.q: What does the term 'Haram' signify in Islamic law?
questions.ex: Haram refers to actions or things that are forbidden or unlawful according to Islamic law.

questions.q: Which of the following is considered a category of actions in Islamic law?

questions.q: What is the significance of Sunnah in Islamic law?
options: It is a collection of historical events
It is a set of philosophical ideas
It clarifies and elaborates upon the Quran
It is solely for moral guidance
questions.ex: The Sunnah of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) serves as a practical example and explanation of the principles found in the Quran, thus clarifying and elaborating on Islamic law.

questions.q: Which historical period is often referred to as the 'Golden Age' of Islamic jurisprudence?
options: The period of the Ottoman Empire
questions.ex: The Abbasid period is often considered the Golden Age of Islamic jurisprudence due to the significant development and compilation of Islamic law by prominent scholars.

questions.q: What is the term for a legal opinion or ruling given by a qualified Islamic scholar?
questions.ex: A fatwa is a non-binding legal opinion or ruling on a point of Islamic law given by a qualified Islamic scholar.

questions.q: Which source of Islamic law is considered the most authentic after the Quran?
questions.ex: After the Quran, the Sunnah (recorded in Hadith) is considered the most authentic source of Islamic law, providing the practical application of Quranic principles.

questions.q: What is the purpose of Usul al-Fiqh?
options: To establish the methodology for deriving Islamic legal rulings
To write historical accounts of Islamic empires
questions.ex: Usul al-Fiqh is the study of the sources and methodology of Islamic jurisprudence, providing the framework for deriving legal rulings from the primary sources.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of an act categorized as Haram?
questions.ex: Consuming alcohol is explicitly forbidden (Haram) in Islamic law.

questions.q: What is the term for the collective body of Islamic jurisprudence?
questions.ex: Fiqh refers to the understanding and knowledge of Islamic law derived from the primary sources, essentially the body of Islamic jurisprudence.

questions.q: Which school of thought in Islamic jurisprudence is primarily followed in North Africa?
questions.ex: The Maliki school of thought is widely followed in North Africa and parts of the Middle East.

questions.q: What is the role of Ijtihad in modern Islamic legal discourse?
options: It is used to reinterpret Islamic law in contemporary contexts
It is limited to purely historical matters
It is only practiced by a select few scholars
questions.ex: Ijtihad remains relevant in modern times for qualified scholars to address new issues and contexts by applying the principles of Islamic law.

questions.q: Which of the following best describes the nature of Shariah?

questions.q: What is the role of custom ('Urf') in Islamic law?
options: It is never considered a source
It can be a secondary source if it does not contradict the Quran and Sunnah

questions.q: What is the term for a permissible or neutral act in Islamic law?

questions.q: What is the term for the process of deriving legal rulings from Islamic texts?
questions.ex: Fiqh is the process of understanding and deriving Islamic legal rulings through the study and interpretation of the primary sources.

questions.q: Which source of Islamic law is based on the reasoned deduction of a ruling for a new case by comparing it to a similar case with a known ruling in the Quran or Sunnah?

questions.q: What does the term 'Fatwa' mean?

questions.q: What is the term for actions that are mandatory or obligatory in Islamic law?

questions.q: What is the purpose of the 'Urf' (custom) as a secondary source in Islamic law?

To provide context and interpretation where the primary sources are not specific
To introduce new laws not found in the primary sources
questions.ex: Custom can be used as a secondary source to provide context and interpretation in areas where the Quran and Sunnah are not explicit, provided it doesn't contradict the primary sources.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of Fiqh?
options: To understand Islamic law and apply it to daily life
questions.ex: Fiqh is the understanding and application of Islamic law derived from the Quran and Sunnah to practical matters.

questions.q: Which of the following is considered a primary source of Fiqh?
questions.ex: The Holy Quran is the most important and primary source of Islamic law and, consequently, Fiqh.

questions.q: What does the term 'Ijtihad' refer to in Fiqh?
options: Independent reasoning to derive Islamic legal rulings
questions.ex: Ijtihad is the process of independent legal reasoning and interpretation of the sources of Islamic law.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a major Sunni school of Fiqh?
questions.ex: The Ja'fari school is a major school of thought within Shia Islam, while Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, and Hanbali are the major Sunni schools.

questions.q: What is 'Qiyas' in the context of Fiqh?
options: Analogy used to derive a ruling for a new issue based on a similar one with an established ruling

questions.q: What does the term 'Ijma' mean in Fiqh?
options: Consensus of the Muslim scholars on a specific legal matter
questions.ex: Ijma refers to the consensus of qualified Muslim scholars on a particular legal issue, which is considered a secondary source of Fiqh.

questions.q: Which school of Fiqh is most prevalent in the Indian subcontinent?

questions.q: What does 'Istihsan' refer to in Fiqh?
options: Juristic preference, setting aside a strict analogy for a more equitable solution

questions.q: Which of the following is a condition for performing Wudu (ablution) according to Fiqh?
options: Being in a state of purity

questions.q: What is the Fiqh ruling on consuming intoxicants?
options: Permitted if prescribed by a doctor

questions.q: Which school of Fiqh is historically associated with North Africa?

questions.q: What is 'Istislah' in Fiqh?

questions.q: What is the Fiqh term for acts that are recommended but not obligatory?

options: Conditions that must be met for a legal act to be valid

questions.q: What is the Fiqh ruling on consuming pork?

options: Necessity or dire need that can temporarily relax certain legal rulings

It is discouraged and disliked by Allah
It is only related to food

options: It is only important in certain situations
It is a sign of faith and trustworthiness
It is not a major concern

It is encouraged, especially towards those who repent
It is only for minor offenses

questions.q: The angel responsible for the mountains is:

questions.q: Angels do not eat or drink.

questions.q: The angel who will be the first to be resurrected on the Day of Judgment is:

questions.q: Angels are messengers between Allah and His:

questions.q: Do angels have free will according to Islamic belief?

questions.q: The angels who protect humans from harm are called:

questions.q: Can humans see angels in their true form?

questions.q: The angels who are present in mosques and gatherings where Allah is remembered are:

questions.q: The primary source of knowledge about angels in Islam is:

questions.q: Angels are involved in executing Allah's commands related to:

questions.q: Which of the following attributes is NOT typically associated with angels in Islam?
options: Ability to choose between good and evil

questions.q: The concept of angels is unique to Islam.

questions.q: Angels can descend to Earth.

questions.q: The greatest of the angels is considered to be:

questions.q: Angels have specific duties assigned to them by Allah.

Only a few angels have duties

questions.q: Belief in angels is a prerequisite for a Muslim.

questions.q: Angels are created with:

questions.q: Which of the following is considered the final and complete book revealed by Allah?

questions.q: Which of the following books are mentioned in the Quran as having been revealed by Allah?

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of the holy books revealed by Allah?
options: To guide humanity to the straight path

questions.q: Which book is considered the most authentic and preserved among the revealed books?

questions.q: The Suhuf-e-Ibrahim (Scrolls of Abraham) were revealed to which prophet?

questions.q: Belief in all the books revealed by Allah is a part of:
questions.ex: Belief in all the books revealed by Allah is one of the six articles of faith in Islam.

questions.q: Which book abrogated the previous scriptures?

questions.q: The original text of which book is believed by Muslims to have been altered over time?
questions.ex: Muslims believe that while the original Tawrat was divine, its current versions have been altered.

questions.q: How many surahs are there in the Holy Quran?
questions.ex: There are 114 surahs in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: What is the shortest surah in the Quran?

questions.q: What is the longest surah in the Quran?

questions.q: The revelation of the Quran began in which month?

questions.q: How long did the revelation of the Holy Quran take?

questions.q: Who was the angel responsible for bringing the revelation of the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?

questions.q: Where was the first revelation of the Quran received?

questions.q: What is the name given to a chapter in the Quran?

questions.q: What is the name given to a verse in the Quran?

questions.q: How many Juz' (parts) are there in the Holy Quran?

questions.q: The Quran is divided into how many Manzils (stages)?

questions.q: What is the meaning of 'Quran'?
questions.ex: The word 'Quran' literally means 'the recitation'.

questions.q: The verses of the Quran are considered:
questions.ex: Muslims believe the verses of the Quran are the direct and literal words of Allah.

questions.q: The compilation of the Quran into a single book was completed during the time of which Caliph?

questions.q: What is the name of the mother of Prophet Isa (Jesus)?

questions.q: Which surah is known as the 'Mother of the Book'?

questions.q: The story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) is primarily found in which surah?

questions.q: Which surah is often recited for protection?

questions.q: The Quran emphasizes the oneness of Allah. This concept is called:

questions.q: The Quran is believed to be preserved in its original form by:

questions.q: What is the significance of Laylat al-Qadr (Night of Power)?
options: It is the night the Prophet was born
It is the night the Quran was first revealed
It is the night of the Hijra
It is the night of the Battle of Badr
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr is the night when the first verses of the Quran were revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: How many Makki surahs are there in the Quran?

questions.q: How many Madani surahs are there in the Quran?

questions.q: The verses revealed in Mecca primarily focus on:

questions.q: The verses revealed in Medina primarily focus on:
options: Belief in Allah and the hereafter
questions.ex: Madani verses primarily focus on establishing the Islamic community, laws, and regulations.

questions.q: What is the Arabic term for the Day of Judgment in Islam?
questions.ex: Qiyamah is the Arabic term for the Day of Judgment, the final assessment of humanity by Allah.

questions.q: Belief in the Day of Judgment is one of the pillars of:
questions.ex: Belief in the Day of Judgment is one of the six pillars of Iman (faith).

questions.q: Who will blow the trumpet to signal the beginning of the Day of Judgment?
questions.ex: Angel Israfil is assigned to blow the trumpet, signaling the end of the world and the beginning of the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: What happens immediately after the first blowing of the trumpet?
options: The mountains will turn to dust
questions.ex: Upon the first blowing of the trumpet, all living beings on Earth and in the heavens will die.

questions.q: After the second blowing of the trumpet, humanity will be resurrected to gather at:
questions.ex: After the second blowing, humanity will be resurrected and gathered on the Plain of Arafat (Midan-e-Hashr) for accountability.

questions.q: The record of each person's deeds will be presented to them on the Day of Judgment. This record is called the:
questions.ex: Each person's record of deeds, known as the Kitab al-A'mal (Book of Deeds), will be presented to them.

questions.q: On the Day of Judgment, deeds will be weighed on the:

questions.q: The bridge that everyone must pass over on the Day of Judgment is called the:
