questions.q: Paradise in Islam is known as:
questions.ex: Jannah is the Arabic term for Paradise, the eternal abode of the righteous.

questions.q: Hellfire in Islam is known as:
questions.ex: Jahannam is the Arabic term for Hellfire, the eternal abode of the wicked.

questions.q: The duration of the Day of Judgment is equivalent to how many earthly years?
questions.ex: According to a Hadith, the length of the Day of Judgment is fifty thousand years.

questions.q: What is one of the major signs of the coming of the Day of Judgment?
questions.ex: The rise of Dajjal (the Antichrist) is considered one of the major signs preceding the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: Who will descend to Earth before the Day of Judgment to defeat Dajjal?
questions.ex: It is believed that Prophet Isa (Jesus) will descend to Earth and defeat Dajjal.

questions.q: The coming of the Mahdi is considered a sign of:
options: The beginning of a new era
The approach of the Day of Judgment
questions.ex: The appearance of the Mahdi is one of the signs indicating the near approach of the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: What will appear from the Earth as a sign of the Day of Judgment?
questions.ex: The appearance of a strange animal from the Earth (Dabbat al-Ard) is a sign of the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: The sun rising from the West is a:

questions.q: What is the state of the Earth before the resurrection on the Day of Judgment?

questions.q: People will be resurrected in what state on the Day of Judgment?
options: As they were in their prime

questions.q: What is the purpose of the accounting (Hisab) on the Day of Judgment?
options: To determine the fate of each individual based on their deeds
To see who is the strongest

questions.q: Those whose good deeds outweigh their bad deeds will enter:

questions.q: What is the intercession (Shafa'ah) on the Day of Judgment?

Prophets and righteous people asking Allah for mercy for believers

questions.q: The first to be resurrected on the Day of Judgment will be:
questions.ex: Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) will be the first to be resurrected on the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: What will be the condition of the sun on the Day of Judgment?
questions.ex: On the Day of Judgment, the sun will be brought very close to the people, causing extreme heat.

questions.q: People will sweat on the Day of Judgment according to their:

questions.q: What is the significance of belief in the Day of Judgment?
options: It encourages people to do good and avoid evil
It only applies to some people
questions.ex: Belief in the Day of Judgment is crucial as it motivates believers to live righteously and be accountable for their actions.

questions.q: What is Barzakh?
options: The state between death and resurrection

questions.q: The questioning in the grave is done by which angels?

questions.q: What will happen to the mountains on the Day of Judgment?

They will sink into the ground

questions.q: What is the meaning of 'Qada and Qadar'?

questions.q: Belief in the messengers of Allah is a pillar of:

questions.q: The final decision of who goes to Jannah or Jahannam rests solely with:

They will be in constant fear

questions.ex: Kawthar is the name of the abundant reservoir granted to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) where believers will quench their thirst on the Day of Judgment.

questions.q: Who is the first person to be judged on the Day of Judgment?

subcategories.title: Belief in Qada and Qadar (Fate and Destiny)

questions.q: What does 'Qada' primarily refer to in the context of Islamic belief?
options: Allah's eternal knowledge and decree of everything that will happen
The implementation of Allah's decree in time
The recording of deeds by angels
questions.ex: 'Qada' refers to Allah's pre-eternal knowledge and decree of everything before it happens.

questions.q: What does 'Qadar' primarily refer to in the context of Islamic belief?
options: Allah's eternal knowledge and decree of everything that will happen
The implementation of Allah's decree in time
The recording of deeds by angels
questions.ex: 'Qadar' refers to the actualization or implementation of Allah's pre-eternal decree (Qada) in time and space.

questions.q: Belief in Qada and Qadar is considered one of the:
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar is one of the six pillars of Islamic faith (Iman).

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a generally accepted understanding of Qada and Qadar in Islam?
options: That everything happens by Allah's will
That humans have no free will
That Allah has knowledge of everything
questions.ex: While everything happens by Allah's will and knowledge, mainstream Islamic belief affirms that humans have a degree of free will and are accountable for their choices.

questions.q: The belief in Qada and Qadar should primarily lead a Muslim to:
options: Strive to do good and trust in Allah
Reject the concept of planning for the future
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar encourages striving for good deeds while trusting in Allah's ultimate plan and wisdom.

questions.q: Which concept is closely related to Qada and Qadar and means trusting in Allah?
questions.ex: Tawakkul means trusting in Allah and relying on Him after taking necessary actions, which is tied to the belief in Qada and Qadar.

questions.q: The record of all that has happened and will happen is believed to be kept in:
questions.ex: Muslims believe that all events are recorded in Al-Lawh Al-Mahfuz (The Preserved Tablet) according to Allah's decree.

questions.q: Which of the following is a benefit of believing in Qada and Qadar?
options: It removes the need for effort
It leads to despair in times of hardship
It brings inner peace and contentment
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar can bring inner peace and contentment by accepting Allah's plan, even during difficulties.

questions.q: When faced with a challenge, how should a Muslim who believes in Qada and Qadar respond?
options: Seek help and strive to overcome it, while trusting in Allah
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar encourages taking action and seeking means while having trust in Allah's help and wisdom.

questions.q: The concept of Qada and Qadar emphasizes:
options: The absolute sovereignty and knowledge of Allah
questions.ex: Qada and Qadar highlight the absolute sovereignty, knowledge, and will of Allah.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT directly contradicted by the belief in Qada and Qadar?
options: The idea that everything is random
The concept of cause and effect
The claim that humans create their own destiny independently of Allah
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar does not negate the concept of cause and effect; rather, causes and effects are part of Allah's decree.

questions.q: Understanding Qada and Qadar helps in developing:
questions.ex: Understanding that everything is ultimately in Allah's hands helps cultivate patience and perseverance through trials.

questions.q: The belief in Qada and Qadar means that whatever happens, good or bad, is:
options: Solely the result of human actions
questions.ex: Muslims believe that both good and bad ultimately originate from Allah's decree and knowledge.

questions.q: Does believing in Qada and Qadar mean that a person is forced to do certain actions?
options: No, humans have a degree of choice
Only in matters of worldly affairs
questions.ex: Islamic belief affirms that humans have a degree of free will and are accountable for their chosen actions, even though everything is within Allah's ultimate knowledge and plan.

questions.q: The purpose of believing in Qada and Qadar is NOT to:
options: Provide comfort in times of difficulty
questions.ex: The belief in Qada and Qadar is meant to strengthen faith and reliance on Allah, not to provide an excuse for sinning.

questions.q: What is the Islamic perspective on planning and taking precautions, despite believing in Qada and Qadar?
options: It is against the concept of Qadar
It is encouraged as part of effort (sabab)
It shows a lack of faith
questions.ex: Islam encourages taking necessary steps and precautions (sabab) while trusting in Allah, as these actions are also part of Allah's decree.

questions.q: If something good happens, a Muslim should primarily attribute it to:
options: The help of other people only
questions.ex: All good is ultimately from Allah's grace and decree, even when it comes through human effort or other means.

questions.q: If something bad happens, a Muslim should primarily attribute it to:
options: Allah's decree, and seek wisdom and patience
questions.ex: While acknowledging potential human error, a Muslim attributes hardship to Allah's decree and seeks patience and understanding.

questions.q: The phrase 'Insha'Allah' (If Allah wills) is related to the belief in:
questions.ex: Saying 'Insha'Allah' acknowledges that all future events depend on Allah's will and decree, reflecting belief in Qada and Qadar.

questions.q: Rejecting the belief in Qada and Qadar is considered to be a rejection of:
options: One of the Five Pillars of Islam
One of the conditions for Hajj
One of the Pillars of Faith (Iman)
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar is a fundamental pillar of Islamic faith (Iman).

questions.q: The knowledge that Allah has of everything that will happen is known as:
questions.ex: Ilmullah refers to the boundless knowledge of Allah, which encompasses all past, present, and future events.

questions.q: Does the belief in Qada and Qadar remove the concept of accountability for one's actions?
options: No, humans are accountable for their choices
questions.ex: Despite believing in Allah's decree, humans are given free will within certain limits and are accountable for the choices they make.

questions.q: How does belief in Qada and Qadar impact a Muslim's attitude towards fear of the future?
options: It provides reassurance and reduces excessive anxiety
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar helps reduce excessive anxiety about the future by acknowledging that the outcome is ultimately in Allah's hands.

questions.q: The concept of 'Taqdeer' is synonymous with:
questions.ex: Taqdeer is another term used to refer to divine decree, fate, or destiny, encompassing the concepts of Qada and Qadar.

questions.q: What is the meaning of the Hadith: 'Work, for everyone is facilitated for that which he was created'?
options: Effort is useless if destiny is fixed
Humans have no role in their destiny
Effort is necessary and is part of one's destiny
Destiny can be changed solely by wishing
questions.ex: This Hadith emphasizes that striving and working are essential parts of realizing what has been destined for a person; effort itself is within the scope of Qadar.

questions.q: The belief in Qada and Qadar teaches us about Allah's:
questions.ex: Qada and Qadar underscore Allah's infinite power, wisdom, and complete control over everything.

questions.q: How does belief in Qada and Qadar influence a Muslim's reaction to success?
options: It causes them to take all the credit
It prompts them to be grateful to Allah
It makes them think it was just luck
questions.ex: Recognizing that success is from Allah's decree leads to gratitude towards Him.

questions.q: The statement 'Alhamdulillah 'ala kulli hal' (Praise be to Allah in all circumstances) is an expression of belief in:
questions.ex: This phrase reflects acceptance and gratitude towards Allah for whatever happens, good or bad, which is a direct result of believing in Qada and Qadar.

questions.q: Which of the following actions is a practical application of believing in Qada and Qadar?
options: Avoiding any planning for the future
Accepting trials with patience and seeking Allah's help
Relying solely on others for support
questions.ex: Belief in Qada and Qadar encourages patience during trials and turning to Allah for assistance.

questions.q: The concept of Qada and Qadar is a source of comfort for Muslims because it reminds them that:
options: They are in complete control of their lives
Allah is in ultimate control and is just
questions.ex: Knowing that a just and wise Allah is in ultimate control provides comfort and reassurance.

questions.q: Does the belief in Qada and Qadar remove the obligation to strive and work for a living?
options: No, striving is a religious obligation
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes the importance of striving and working for one's sustenance; this effort is seen as part of fulfilling Allah's decree.

questions.q: The concept of Qada and Qadar is often misunderstood to mean fatalism, which implies:
options: That human effort has no effect
questions.ex: Fatalism suggests a predetermined outcome regardless of effort, which is not the mainstream Islamic understanding of Qada and Qadar.

questions.q: Belief in Qada and Qadar encourages a Muslim to:
options: Be proactive and rely on Allah
questions.ex: It encourages a balance between taking action and relying on Allah's wisdom and plan.

questions.q: The best way to understand Qada and Qadar is through the teachings of:
questions.ex: The authentic understanding of Qada and Qadar is derived from the primary sources of Islam, the Quran and Sunnah.

questions.q: Which Islamic month is significant for the fasting of Ramadan?
questions.ex: Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and is observed by Muslims worldwide as a month of fasting (sawm), prayer, reflection, and community.

questions.q: Eid al-Fitr marks the end of which Islamic observance?
questions.ex: Eid al-Fitr is a religious holiday celebrated by Muslims worldwide that marks the end of the month-long dawn-to-sunset fasting of Ramadan.

questions.q: The sacrifice of an animal is a significant ritual during which Islamic festival?
questions.ex: Eid al-Adha, also known as the 'Festival of Sacrifice', commemorates the willingness of Ibrahim (Abraham) to sacrifice his son Ishmael as an act of obedience to Allah.

questions.q: Which Islamic month is considered the holiest month after Ramadan?
questions.ex: Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar and is considered one of the four sacred months. Ashura, the tenth day of Muharram, is a significant day.

questions.q: Laylat al-Qadr, the Night of Power, is believed to occur in which Islamic month?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr is considered the holiest night of the year in Islam and is believed to have occurred during one of the last ten odd nights of Ramadan.

questions.q: The Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca is known as:
questions.ex: Hajj is an annual Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, the holiest city for Muslims, and a mandatory religious duty for Muslims that must be carried out at least once in their lifetime by all adult Muslims who are physically and financially capable of undertaking the journey.

questions.q: In which Islamic month does the Hajj pilgrimage take place?
questions.ex: The Hajj pilgrimage takes place during the last month of the Islamic calendar, Dhu al-Hijjah.

questions.q: Ashura is a significant day in which Islamic month?
questions.ex: Ashura falls on the 10th day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: Mawlid, the birthday of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), is observed in which Islamic month?
questions.ex: Mawlid is the observance of the birthday of the Islamic prophet Muhammad which is celebrated in the third month of the Islamic calendar, Rabi' al-Awwal.

questions.q: Laylat al-Miraj commemorates the night journey and ascension of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). In which month does it occur?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Miraj, also known as the Night Journey and Ascension, is believed to have occurred on the 27th night of the month of Rajab.

questions.q: The start of the Islamic New Year is in which month?
questions.ex: Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar and marks the beginning of the new Islamic year.

questions.q: Fasting during the month of Ramadan is one of the:
questions.ex: Fasting during Ramadan (Sawm) is one of the five pillars of Islam.

questions.q: The day of Arafah is a crucial part of which Islamic observance?
questions.ex: The Day of Arafah is the second day of the Hajj pilgrimage, and it falls on the 9th day of Dhu al-Hijjah.

questions.q: Which event is commemorated on Eid al-Adha?
questions.ex: Eid al-Adha commemorates the test of faith faced by Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) when he was commanded to sacrifice his son.

questions.q: The Battle of Badr took place in which Islamic month?
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr, the first major battle between the Muslims of Medina and the Quraysh of Mecca, took place in the month of Ramadan in 2 AH.

questions.q: The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah was signed during which Islamic month?
questions.ex: The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah was an important treaty between Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the Quraysh tribe of Mecca in March 628 CE (Dhu al-Qadah 6 AH).

questions.q: The Conquest of Mecca occurred in which Islamic month?
questions.ex: The Conquest of Mecca, when Muslims gained control of Mecca, took place in Ramadan in 8 AH.

questions.q: The month of Muharram is particularly significant for which branch of Islam?
questions.ex: Muharram is particularly significant for Shia Muslims as it commemorates the Battle of Karbala and the martyrdom of Husayn ibn Ali.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT one of the four sacred months in Islam?
questions.ex: The four sacred months are Dhu al-Qadah, Dhu al-Hijjah, Muharram, and Rajab.

questions.q: The first revelation of the Holy Quran to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is commemorated during which night?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr (The Night of Power) is believed to be the night when the first verses of the Quran were revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which Islamic festival marks the willingness of Prophet Ibrahim to sacrifice his son?
questions.ex: Eid al-Adha commemorates Prophet Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son as an act of obedience to Allah.

questions.q: The fasting in Ramadan is obligatory for all adult Muslims who are:
questions.ex: Fasting in Ramadan is obligatory for adult Muslims who are healthy, sane, and not traveling.

questions.q: The Eid prayer is performed in congregation on the mornings of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. What is the ruling on this prayer?
questions.ex: The Eid prayer is considered Wajib (compulsory) by most scholars, meaning it is a highly emphasized communal duty.

questions.q: The practice of giving charity at the end of Ramadan is known as:
questions.ex: Fitrana (Zakat al-Fitr) is a mandatory charity given by Muslims at the end of Ramadan before the Eid al-Fitr prayer.

questions.q: The Day of Ashura is historically significant for which event?
options: The martyrdom of Husayn ibn Ali
questions.ex: For Shia Muslims, Ashura commemorates the martyrdom of Husayn ibn Ali, the grandson of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), at the Battle of Karbala.

questions.q: Which month is known as the month of migration (Hijra) of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Medina?
questions.ex: While the Hijra itself took place over a period, the Islamic calendar starts with the month of Muharram, commemorating the significance of the migration.

questions.q: The observance of Mawlid is a celebration of:
questions.ex: Mawlid is the celebration of the birth of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which night during Ramadan is considered the most blessed and when prayers are believed to be most likely answered?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr is highly revered as the night when the first verses of the Quran were revealed and is considered the most blessed night for worship.

questions.q: The month of Dhu al-Hijjah is significant because it includes:
questions.ex: Dhu al-Hijjah is the month when the Hajj pilgrimage takes place and is followed by the celebration of Eid al-Adha.

questions.q: Which Islamic event marks the end of the fasting month?
questions.ex: Eid al-Fitr is the festival that marks the successful completion of fasting during Ramadan.

questions.q: The stoning of the Jamarat is a ritual performed during:
questions.ex: The stoning of the Jamarat, symbolizing the stoning of the devil, is a key ritual during the Hajj pilgrimage.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of fasting in Ramadan?
options: To feel hunger of the poor
questions.ex: The primary purpose of fasting in Ramadan is to develop piety and God-consciousness (Taqwa).

questions.q: The farewell pilgrimage of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) took place in which year of the Hijra?
questions.ex: The Farewell Pilgrimage of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) took place in 10 AH (632 CE).

questions.q: The Isra' and Mi'raj refers to:
questions.ex: Isra' and Mi'raj are the two parts of a single journey that Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is said to have taken in one night.

questions.q: The Islamic calendar is a lunar calendar, meaning its months are based on the cycles of the:
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar is a lunar calendar, and the beginning of each month is determined by the sighting of the new moon.

questions.q: How many months are there in the Islamic calendar?
questions.ex: There are twelve months in the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: The voluntary fasting on the day of Ashura is recommended because it commemorates:
options: The crossing of the Red Sea by Moses and the Israelites
questions.ex: Voluntary fasting on the Day of Ashura is recommended based on narrations about Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) and the deliverance of the Israelites from Pharaoh.

questions.q: Which Islamic festival is celebrated to commemorate the Prophet's journey to Jerusalem and then to the heavens?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Miraj commemorates the Night Journey (Isra) and Ascension (Miraj) of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The month of Sha'ban is known for being the month immediately preceding:
questions.ex: Sha'ban is the eighth month of the Islamic calendar, preceding the holy month of Ramadan.

questions.q: Which historical event is commemorated on the 17th of Ramadan?
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr, the first major battle in Islamic history, took place on the 17th of Ramadan, 2 AH.

questions.q: Who was the first wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the first person to accept Islam?
questions.ex: Khadija bint Khawaylid was the first wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the first person, male or female, to embrace Islam.

questions.q: Which daughter of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is highly revered in Islam and is the mother of Hasan and Husayn?
questions.ex: Fatima bint Muhammad is the youngest daughter of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and is a central figure of reverence, especially in Shia Islam. She was the wife of Ali ibn Abi Talib and mother of Hasan and Husayn.

questions.q: Which wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is known for her extensive knowledge and narration of Hadith?
options: Umm Salama Hind bint Abi Umayya
questions.ex: Aisha bint Abu Bakr narrated a large number of Hadith and is considered a significant source of knowledge regarding the Sunnah of the Prophet (PBUH).

questions.q: Who was the mother of Prophet Musa (Moses) and is mentioned in the Quran?
questions.ex: While her name is not explicitly mentioned in the Quran, Islamic tradition identifies Jochebed as the mother of Prophet Musa (Moses).

questions.q: Which queen is mentioned in the Quran and is believed to have accepted Islam after interacting with Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon)?
questions.ex: The Quran narrates the story of Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon) and the Queen of Sheba (often identified as Bilqis), who eventually submitted to God.

questions.q: Who was the foster mother of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Halimah bint Abi Dhu'ayb was the wet nurse and foster mother of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which Sahabiyyah (female companion) is known for her bravery and participation in battles, including the Battle of Uhud?
questions.ex: Umm Ammarah (Nusaybah bint Ka'b) was a courageous female companion who actively participated in battles, defending Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) at Uhud.

questions.q: Who was the wife of Prophet Ayyub (Job) and remained steadfast in her faith during his severe trials?
questions.ex: According to Islamic tradition, the wife of Prophet Ayyub (Job) was named Rahmah bint Ephraim, and she was a source of support and patience during his prolonged illness.

questions.q: Which woman is revered for her piety and is the mother of Prophet Isa (Jesus)?
questions.ex: Maryam bint Imran (Mary, the mother of Jesus) is highly honored in Islam for her piety and miraculous conception of Prophet Isa (Jesus).

questions.q: Who was the daughter of Abu Bakr and the wife of Zubayr ibn al-Awwam, known for her intelligence and courage?
questions.ex: Asma bint Abi Bakr, daughter of the first Caliph, was known for her intelligence and courage, famously assisting her father and the Prophet (PBUH) during their migration to Medina.

questions.q: Which woman was known for her wealth and business acumen before her marriage to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
options: Umm Salama Hind bint Abi Umayya
questions.ex: Khadija bint Khawaylid was a successful businesswoman before she proposed marriage to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Who was the wife of Prophet Musa (Moses) who he met in Midian?
questions.ex: Prophet Musa (Moses) married Zipporah, the daughter of Jethro (Shu'aib in Islamic tradition), after he fled from Egypt to Midian.

questions.q: Which queen in Islamic history is known for her justice and wise rule in Yemen?
questions.ex: Queen Arwa al-Sulayhi was a notable ruler in Yemen known for her justice and development during the Sulayhid dynasty.

questions.q: Which wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was the daughter of Abu Sufyan?
options: Umm Habiba Ramla bint Abi Sufyan
questions.ex: Umm Habiba Ramla bint Abi Sufyan was a wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the daughter of Abu Sufyan, who was initially a staunch opponent of Islam.

questions.q: Who was the first martyr in Islam?
questions.ex: Sumayyah bint Khabbat is considered the first martyr in Islam, who was tortured and killed for her belief in Islam.

questions.q: Which woman is known for her sacrifice during the Battle of Karbala and is highly revered in Shia Islam?
questions.ex: Zainab bint Ali, the granddaughter of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), played a crucial role in preserving the message of the events of Karbala through her powerful speeches.

questions.q: Who was the wife of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) and the mother of Prophet Ishaq (Isaac)?
questions.ex: Sarah was the wife of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) and the mother of Prophet Ishaq (Isaac).

questions.q: Which woman is known for establishing the first university in the world in Fez, Morocco?
questions.ex: Fatima al-Fihri founded the University of Al-Qarawiyyin in Fez, Morocco in 859 CE, which is considered the oldest continually operating university in the world.

questions.q: Who was the daughter of Umar ibn al-Khattab and a wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
options: Umm Salama Hind bint Abi Umayya
questions.ex: Hafsa bint Umar was a wife of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the daughter of the second Caliph, Umar ibn al-Khattab.

questions.q: Which woman is known as the 'mother of the believers'?
questions.ex: All the wives of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) are collectively referred to as the 'Mothers of the Believers' in the Quran.

questions.q: Who was the wife of Pharaoh in the time of Prophet Musa (Moses) who is mentioned in the Quran for her faith?
questions.ex: Asiya bint Muzahim, the wife of Pharaoh, is mentioned in the Quran as a woman of great faith who rejected her husband's tyranny and embraced the message of Allah.

questions.q: Which woman is known as a prominent Sufi mystic and poet?
questions.ex: Rabia al-Adawiyya was an influential female Muslim mystic and poet of the 8th century.

questions.q: Who was the grandmother of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) who cared for him after his mother's death?
questions.ex: Fatima bint Amr was the grandmother of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the wife of Abdul Muttalib. She cared for him after his mother, Aminah, passed away.

questions.q: Which woman was known for her beautiful voice and recitation of the Quran?
questions.ex: Umm Warqa bint Abdullah was a female companion known for her beautiful recitation of the Quran, and the Prophet (PBUH) permitted her to lead the women of her household in prayer.

questions.q: Who was the daughter of Khuwailid and the sister of Khadija, and a notable figure in early Islam?
questions.ex: Hala bint Khawaylid was the sister of Khadija bint Khawaylid and an early supporter of Islam.

questions.q: Which woman played a significant role in preserving and transmitting the knowledge of Hadith?
questions.ex: Aisha bint Abu Bakr is one of the most prolific narrators of Hadith and a crucial source for understanding the Prophet's Sunnah.

questions.q: Who was the mother of Prophet Ismail (Ishmael)?
questions.ex: Hagar was the second wife of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) and the mother of Prophet Ismail (Ishmael).

questions.q: Which woman is known for her patience and steadfastness during the boycott of the Banu Hashim?
questions.ex: Khadija bint Khawaylid endured hardship and remained supportive of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) during the difficult period of the boycott.

questions.q: Who was the first wife of Prophet Nuh (Noah)?
questions.ex: According to some Islamic interpretations, Wailah was the wife of Prophet Nuh (Noah) and is mentioned in the Quran as one who did not believe.

questions.q: Which woman was the wife of Prophet Lut (Lot) and is mentioned in the Quran as one who did not follow his message?
questions.ex: The Quran refers to the wife of Prophet Lut (Lot) as someone who was among those who remained behind with the disbelievers when the punishment came.

questions.q: Who was the daughter of Prophet Shu'aib and the wife of Prophet Musa?
questions.ex: Zipporah was the daughter of Prophet Shu'aib (Jethro) and she married Prophet Musa (Moses).

questions.q: Which woman is known for her beautiful voice and recitation of poetry, and later accepted Islam?
questions.ex: Khansa bint Amr was a renowned Arab poetess known for her elegies before accepting Islam.

questions.q: Who was the first female teacher in Islam?
questions.ex: Al-Shifa bint Abdullah was a learned woman who was permitted by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) to teach writing to women, making her a pioneer in female education in Islam.

questions.q: Which woman is known for her significant contributions to Islamic literature and poetry in later centuries?
questions.ex: Aisha al-Ba'uniyya was a prolific female writer and poet from the Mamluk period, known for her Sufi poetry and prose.

questions.q: Who was the mother of Prophet Yunus (Jonah)?
questions.ex: The name of Prophet Yunus (Jonah)'s mother is not explicitly mentioned in the Holy Quran.

questions.q: Which woman was known for her bravery and skill in medicine and nursing during battles?
questions.ex: Rufaydah bint Sa'd al-Aslamiyya is considered the first female Muslim nurse and surgeon, known for her medical contributions during early Islamic battles.

questions.q: Who was the daughter of Imam Husayn and played a role in narrating the events of Karbala?
questions.ex: Sakina bint Husayn, the daughter of Imam Husayn, is a beloved figure in Shia Islam known for her suffering and endurance after the Battle of Karbala.

questions.q: Which woman was known for her knowledge of the Quran and was entrusted with a copy of the Mushaf compiled during Uthman's caliphate?
questions.ex: Hafsa bint Umar was entrusted with one of the original copies of the Quranic text compiled during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan.

questions.q: Who was the wife of Prophet Zakariyya (Zechariah) and the mother of Prophet Yahya (John the Baptist)?
questions.ex: Elizabeth, the wife of Prophet Zakariyya (Zechariah), was the mother of Prophet Yahya (John the Baptist). Both are mentioned in the Quran.

subcategories.title: Rights in Islam (Women, Parents, Neighbors, etc.)

questions.q: According to Islam, which of the following is a right of parents over their children?
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes the importance of treating parents with kindness, respect, and providing for them financially if they are in need.

questions.q: What is the Islamic perspective on the rights of women in marriage?
options: They have no rights in marriage
They have equal rights and responsibilities to men
Their rights are limited compared to men
They are solely responsible for household duties
questions.ex: Islam grants women equal rights and responsibilities within the framework of marriage, including the right to a dowry (mehr), maintenance, and the right to seek divorce under certain conditions.

questions.q: Which of the following is considered a right of neighbors in Islam?
options: To be financially assisted whenever they ask
To be informed about all your personal matters
To be treated kindly and not harmed
To be invited to every family gathering
questions.ex: Islam places great importance on the rights of neighbors, emphasizing kindness, good treatment, and avoiding causing them any harm or inconvenience.

questions.q: What is the significance of upholding the rights of the poor and needy in Islam?
options: It is optional for Muslims to help them
It is a fundamental aspect of Islamic faith and practice
It is only required if they are relatives
It is discouraged to give them too much
questions.ex: Providing for the poor and needy is a fundamental pillar of Islam (Zakat) and a highly encouraged act of charity (Sadaqah), reflecting the social justice aspect of the religion.

questions.q: In Islam, what is the right of a child upon their parents?
options: To be given everything they desire
To be neglected if the parents are busy
To be provided with sustenance, education, and moral upbringing
To be forced to follow a specific career path
questions.ex: Parents have a responsibility to provide for their children's basic needs, ensure they receive an education, and instill in them good morals and Islamic values.

questions.q: What does Islam teach about the rights of orphans?
options: They should be ignored and left to fend for themselves
They should be treated with kindness, care, and their wealth protected
They should be exploited for labor
questions.ex: Islam strongly emphasizes the protection and care of orphans, urging Muslims to treat them kindly, look after their needs, and manage their inheritance justly.

questions.q: According to Islamic teachings, who has the greatest right to a person's good companionship after Allah and His Messenger?
questions.ex: Several narrations highlight the immense importance of respecting and honoring one's parents, often placing their rights second only to the rights of Allah and the Prophet (PBUH).

questions.q: What is the Islamic view on the rights of the elderly?
options: They should be left to live on their own
They should be treated with respect, dignity, and compassion
They are a burden on society
questions.ex: Islam teaches the importance of honoring and caring for the elderly, showing them respect, providing for their needs, and valuing their wisdom.

questions.q: What are the rights of a husband over his wife in Islam?
options: Absolute authority and control over her
To be obeyed in all matters as long as they are not against Islamic teachings
To prevent her from interacting with her family
questions.ex: A husband has the right to be obeyed in matters that are not contrary to Islamic principles, and the wife has the right to maintenance and kind treatment.

questions.q: What is the Islamic stance on the rights of non-Muslims living in a Muslim society?
options: They have the right to live in peace and security, and their property and places of worship should be protected
They should be forced to convert to Islam
They should be treated as second-class citizens
questions.ex: Islam guarantees basic rights to non-Muslims living under Islamic rule, including the right to practice their religion, protection of their property, and security.

questions.q: Which of the following is a right of guests in Islam?
options: To be treated generously and with hospitality
To be charged for their stay
To be asked to leave quickly
questions.ex: Islam encourages Muslims to be hospitable towards their guests and treat them with generosity and respect.

questions.q: What are the rights of workers in Islam?
options: To be exploited for maximum labor
To be paid their wages fairly and on time
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes the importance of treating workers justly, paying them their dues promptly, and not overburdening them with work.

questions.q: In Islam, what is the right of animals?
options: To be treated with kindness and not subjected to unnecessary suffering
To be used solely for human benefit without regard for their well-being
questions.ex: Islam teaches compassion towards animals, forbidding cruelty and emphasizing that they should be treated with kindness and provided with adequate care.

questions.q: What is the right of the environment in Islam?
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes stewardship over the environment, encouraging Muslims to protect and preserve it as a trust from Allah.

questions.q: According to Islamic teachings, who is most deserving of your good treatment?
questions.ex: Islamic teachings strongly emphasize the paramount importance of respecting and honoring one's mother.

questions.q: What is the right of the traveler in Islam?
options: To be ignored and not helped
To be assisted and provided for if in need
To be charged extra for services
questions.ex: Islam encourages Muslims to help and assist travelers who are in need.

questions.q: What does Islam say about the rights of the sick?
options: They should be visited, cared for, and prayed for
They are a burden on others
questions.ex: Visiting and caring for the sick is a highly recommended act in Islam, and they have the right to be looked after.

questions.q: What is the right of a Muslim over another Muslim?
options: To be treated with brotherhood, respect, and mutual support
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes the strong bond of brotherhood among Muslims, highlighting the rights they have over each other, such as greeting, visiting the sick, and attending funerals.

questions.q: In Islam, what is the right of a dead Muslim?
options: To be washed, shrouded, prayed over, and buried properly
questions.ex: Islam outlines specific rights and rituals for the deceased Muslim, including washing the body, shrouding, offering funeral prayer, and proper burial.

questions.q: What is the Islamic teaching regarding the rights of the weak and vulnerable in society?
options: They should be protected, supported, and treated with compassion
They are responsible for their own hardship
questions.ex: Islam strongly advocates for the protection and support of the weak, vulnerable, and oppressed members of society.

questions.q: Which of the following is a key principle related to rights in Islam?
options: Rights are only for a select few
Rights are universally applicable based on one's relationship with Allah and other creations
Rights are determined by social status
questions.ex: Islamic teachings on rights are based on the concept of justice and equity, applying to individuals based on their relationship with Allah and their interactions with others.

questions.q: What is the emphasis on the rights of the spouse in Islam?
options: Spouses have no rights over each other
Mutual rights and responsibilities for a harmonious relationship
questions.ex: Islam outlines mutual rights and responsibilities for both husbands and wives to foster a balanced and harmonious marital relationship.

questions.q: What is the right of a teacher over a student in Islam?
options: To be served by the student
questions.ex: Islam emphasizes the importance of respecting teachers and giving them due attention and regard in the pursuit of knowledge.

questions.q: What does Islam say about the rights of animals used for sacrifice?
options: They can be treated cruelly before sacrifice
They must be treated kindly and slaughtered humanely
Their rights are irrelevant before sacrifice
They should be starved before sacrifice
questions.ex: Even animals designated for sacrifice must be treated with kindness and slaughtered in a humane manner according to Islamic guidelines.

questions.q: What is the importance of fulfilling contracts and promises in Islam?
options: It is a religious obligation and a sign of faith
It is only important for major agreements
It is only necessary if it benefits you
questions.ex: Fulfilling contracts and promises is a significant aspect of Islamic ethics and is considered a sign of a true believer.

questions.q: In Islam, what is the right of the road/path?
options: To be blocked for personal use
To be kept clear and used respectfully
To be used as a personal dumping ground
questions.ex: Islam teaches the importance of respecting public spaces like roads and paths, keeping them clear and not causing inconvenience to others.

questions.q: What is the Islamic perspective on the right to education?
options: Education is not important in Islam
Seeking knowledge is a religious obligation for both men and women
Education is discouraged as it can lead to deviation
questions.ex: Islam strongly encourages the pursuit of knowledge and considers it a religious obligation for both males and females.

questions.q: What is the right of a debtor in Islam?
options: To be harassed and treated harshly
To be given respite if unable to pay back the debt immediately
To have their property seized immediately
questions.ex: Islam encourages giving a debtor who is in difficulty more time to repay their debt and prohibits harsh treatment.

questions.q: What does Islam say about the rights of workers' safety?
options: Employers are obligated to ensure the safety and well-being of their workers
Workers are responsible for their own safety
Safety measures are an unnecessary expense
questions.ex: Islamic teachings emphasize the responsibility of employers to provide a safe working environment and ensure the well-being of their employees.

questions.q: What is the right of a prisoner in Islam?
options: To be treated justly and provided with basic necessities
To be denied food and water
questions.ex: Islam mandates that even prisoners should be treated with justice, provided with basic needs, and not subjected to torture or inhumane treatment.

questions.q: What is the Islamic perspective on the right to freedom of expression?
options: It is unlimited and without boundaries
It is permissible as long as it does not harm others, spread falsehoods, or violate Islamic principles
It is only for those in power
questions.ex: Islam allows for freedom of expression within certain boundaries, emphasizing responsible speech that does not cause harm, spread misinformation, or contradict core Islamic values.

questions.q: What is the right of a guest on the host in Islam?
options: To be treated with hospitality and honor for a limited period
To be treated as a servant
To be asked to perform chores
questions.ex: Islam encourages hosts to treat their guests with generosity, respect, and honor, typically for a duration of up to three days.

questions.q: What does Islam say about the rights of the deceased Muslim's family?
options: They have the right to mourn and receive support from the community
They should be blamed for the death
questions.ex: Islam encourages the community to support and console the family of the deceased and allows them a period of mourning.

questions.q: What is the right of a creditor in Islam?
options: To have their loan repaid according to the agreed terms
To forgive the debt regardless of their ability
To seize property before the repayment date
questions.ex: Islam upholds the right of a creditor to have their loan repaid as agreed, while also encouraging leniency if the debtor is in difficulty.

questions.q: What is the Islamic perspective on the rights of a wife to receive maintenance from her husband?
options: It is a mandatory right of the wife
It is only required if she is unable to work
It is a voluntary act of charity
questions.ex: A husband is obligated in Islam to provide for the maintenance (food, shelter, clothing) of his wife.

questions.q: What is the right of a child to be named properly in Islam?
options: It is a right of the child to be given a good and meaningful name
questions.ex: Islam encourages parents to give their children good and meaningful names.

questions.q: What does Islam say about the rights of a person's reputation?
options: It is to be protected and not slandered or backbited
questions.ex: Islam strictly prohibits slandering and backbiting, emphasizing the importance of protecting a person's reputation.

subcategories.title: Islamic Sects and Schools of Thought

questions.q: The largest denomination of Islam is:
questions.ex: Sunni Islam constitutes the vast majority of Muslims worldwide.

questions.q: Followers of which school of thought in Sunni Islam are predominantly found in the Indian subcontinent?
questions.ex: The Hanafi school is the most followed school of thought in Sunni Islam in regions like Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh.

questions.q: The primary difference between Sunni and Shia Islam lies in the issue of:
questions.ex: The main historical division between Sunni and Shia Muslims originated from a dispute over the succession to the leadership of the Muslim community after the death of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Twelver Shia Islam believes in a succession of how many Imams after Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)?
questions.ex: Twelver Shia Muslims believe in a lineage of twelve divinely ordained Imams as the spiritual and political successors to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT considered one of the four major schools of thought (Madhhabs) within Sunni Islam?
questions.ex: Ismaili is a branch of Shia Islam, not one of the four major Sunni schools of jurisprudence (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, Hanbali).

questions.q: Sufism is often described as the ______ dimension of Islam.
questions.ex: Sufism focuses on the spiritual and mystical aspects of Islam, seeking direct personal experience of God.

questions.q: The term 'Wahhabism' is often associated with a conservative and reformist movement within which branch of Islam?
questions.ex: Wahhabism is a conservative, fundamentalist interpretation of Sunni Islam attributed to Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab.

questions.q: Which school of thought is prevalent in North Africa?
questions.ex: The Maliki school of jurisprudence is predominantly followed in North Africa and parts of the Arabian Peninsula.

questions.q: The Zaydi branch of Shia Islam is primarily found in:
questions.ex: The Zaydi Shia school of thought is historically and predominantly found in Yemen.

questions.q: Which school of thought is considered the most traditionalist among the four Sunni schools?
questions.ex: The Hanbali school is generally considered the most conservative and strict in its adherence to the literal interpretation of Islamic texts.

questions.q: The term 'Madhhab' in Islam refers to:
options: A school of thought in Islamic jurisprudence
questions.ex: A Madhhab is a school of thought or legal school in Islamic jurisprudence (Fiqh).

questions.q: Which school of thought is followed by the majority of Muslims in Egypt and Southeast Asia?
questions.ex: The Shafi'i school is widely followed in Egypt, Southeast Asia, and parts of East Africa.

questions.q: The term 'Ahl al-Bayt' (People of the House) is particularly significant in which branch of Islam?
questions.ex: Ahl al-Bayt, referring to the family of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), holds a central and revered position in Shia Islam.

questions.q: The Kharijites were an early Islamic sect known for their:
questions.ex: The Kharijites were known for their strict and radical interpretation of Islamic law and their stance against rulers they deemed unrighteous.

questions.q: Which of the following is a major branch of Shia Islam?
questions.ex: Ismaili is a significant branch within Shia Islam, distinct from the larger Twelver Shia denomination.

questions.q: The Maturidi and Ash'ari are two major schools of thought within Islamic:
questions.ex: Maturidi and Ash'ari are the two dominant schools of Sunni Islamic theology (Aqidah).

questions.q: Which school of thought emphasizes the importance of community consensus (Ijma) and local custom (Urf) in legal rulings?
questions.ex: The Hanafi school is known for its emphasis on reasoning (Ra'y) and considering community consensus (Ijma) and local customs (Urf).

questions.q: The term 'Salafism' refers to a movement that advocates for a return to the practices of the:
questions.ex: Salafism is a fundamentalist, reformist movement that advocates for a return to what its adherents believe were the practices of the early Muslim community (Salaf al-Salih).

questions.q: Which school of thought is predominant in Saudi Arabia and Qatar?
questions.ex: The Hanbali school is the dominant school of jurisprudence in Saudi Arabia and Qatar.

questions.q: The term 'Ijtihad' in Islamic law refers to:
questions.ex: Ijtihad is the process of independent reasoning or the thorough exertion of a jurist's mental faculty in finding a solution to a legal question.

questions.q: Which of the following is a mystical order within Sufism?
questions.ex: The Naqshbandi is one of the major Sufi orders (Tariqahs).

questions.q: The main source of difference in legal rulings between the Sunni schools of thought is the interpretation and application of:
questions.ex: While all Sunni schools rely on the Quran and Sunnah, their differences arise from varying methodologies in interpreting and applying these primary sources.

questions.q: Which school of thought places significant emphasis on the traditions of the people of Medina?
questions.ex: Imam Malik, the founder of the Maliki school, relied heavily on the practices and traditions of the people of Medina (Amal Ahl al-Madinah).

questions.q: The term 'Tariqah' in the context of Sufism refers to:
questions.ex: Tariqah refers to a Sufi order or path, which is a spiritual lineage and methodology for traversing the Sufi path.

questions.q: Which school of thought is known for its strict methodology in accepting Hadith?
questions.ex: The Hanbali school is known for its strict reliance on the Hadith and minimal use of personal opinion or analogy.

questions.q: The difference between Usul al-Fiqh and Fiqh is that Usul al-Fiqh deals with:
options: The sources and methodologies of Islamic law
questions.ex: Usul al-Fiqh refers to the sources and methodologies used in deriving Islamic legal rulings, while Fiqh is the body of actual legal rulings.

questions.q: Which branch of Shia Islam is known for the concept of the 'Living Imam'?
questions.ex: Ismaili Shia Islam emphasizes the continuation of the Imamate in a living, present Imam.

questions.q: The term 'Kalam' in Islamic studies refers to:
questions.ex: Kalam is the Islamic philosophical theology that seeks to defend Islamic doctrine through argument and reason.

questions.q: Which of the following is a reformist movement within Sunni Islam that emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries?
questions.ex: The Deobandi movement originated in British India in the late 19th century as a reformist movement within Hanafi Sunni Islam.

questions.q: The Barelvi movement in the Indian subcontinent is known for its emphasis on:
options: Sufi practices and reverence for saints
questions.ex: The Barelvi movement is a sub-sect within Sunni Islam in the Indian subcontinent that emphasizes Sufi practices, reverence for saints, and celebrating religious festivals.

questions.q: Which school of thought allows for the use of 'Istislah' (considering public interest) as a source of law?
questions.ex: The Maliki school utilizes Istislah (consideration of public interest) as a supplementary source of law.

questions.q: The term 'Bid'ah' in Islamic context refers to:
questions.ex: Bid'ah is a concept in Islamic law that refers to innovation in religious matters, generally considered discouraged or prohibited depending on its nature.

questions.q: Which of the following is a school of thought within Twelver Shia Islam?
questions.ex: The Ja'fari school is the primary school of jurisprudence within Twelver Shia Islam.

questions.q: The Mu'tazila were a rationalist school of theology in early Islam known for their emphasis on:
options: The literal interpretation of the Quran
questions.ex: The Mu'tazila school of theology emphasized the absolute transcendence and unity of God, often interpreting Quranic verses metaphorically to avoid anthropomorphism.

questions.q: Which of the following is a criterion for accepting a Hadith as authentic in Islamic scholarship?
options: Its alignment with the personal opinions of scholars
The reliability and chain of narrators (Isnad)
questions.ex: The authenticity of a Hadith is primarily determined by the reliability of its narrators and the integrity of the chain of transmission (Isnad).

questions.q: The term 'Ijma' in Islamic jurisprudence refers to:
questions.ex: Ijma refers to the consensus of the Muslim community or scholars on a particular legal matter.

questions.q: Which of the four Sunni schools is considered to have the most geographically widespread followers?
questions.ex: The Hanafi school has the largest number of followers globally, spread across South Asia, Central Asia, Turkey, and parts of the Middle East.

subcategories.title: Islamic Contributions to Science and Knowledge

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is considered the 'father of algebra'?
questions.ex: Al-Khwarizmi was a Persian polymath whose work on algorithms and the introduction of Indian numerals to the West were fundamental to the development of algebra.

questions.q: The concept of zero and the decimal system were significantly advanced and transmitted to Europe by scholars from the Islamic world. These concepts originated from which civilization?
questions.ex: The concept of zero and the decimal system originated in India and were adopted and further developed by Islamic scholars, who then introduced them to Europe.

questions.q: Which famous Islamic physician wrote 'The Canon of Medicine', a standard medical text for centuries in both the Islamic world and Europe?
questions.ex: Ibn Sina, also known as Avicenna, was a renowned physician and philosopher whose comprehensive medical encyclopedia, 'The Canon of Medicine', was widely used for hundreds of years.

questions.q: The astrolabe, a complex instrument used for navigation and astronomical measurements, was significantly refined and developed by scholars during the Islamic Golden Age. What was one of its primary uses?
questions.ex: Astrolabes were crucial for determining prayer times (Salah) and the direction of the Kaaba (Qibla) by measuring the position of celestial bodies.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his pioneering work in optics and is considered the 'father of optics'?
questions.ex: Ibn al-Haytham, known as Alhazen in the West, made significant contributions to the field of optics through his experiments and theories of vision.

questions.q: The House of Wisdom (Bayt al-Hikma) was a major intellectual center during the Abbasid Caliphate, famous for its translations of texts from various civilizations. In which city was it located?
questions.ex: The House of Wisdom was a renowned library, translation institute, and academy in Baghdad, which played a vital role in the preservation and translation of ancient knowledge.

questions.q: Which field of study saw significant advancements in the Islamic world, leading to the development of hospitals, surgical instruments, and medical encyclopedias?
questions.ex: Islamic scholars and physicians made remarkable strides in medicine, establishing hospitals, conducting research, and writing comprehensive medical texts.

questions.q: The development of trigonometry as a distinct branch of mathematics is significantly attributed to scholars from the Islamic world. Which function was particularly studied and developed?
questions.ex: Islamic mathematicians made important contributions to trigonometry, particularly in the development and application of the sine function.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive work on geography, including detailed maps and descriptions of various regions?
questions.ex: Al-Idrisi was a renowned geographer who created detailed maps and a comprehensive geographical text titled 'Tabula Rogeriana'.

questions.q: The concept of the experimental method was emphasized and utilized by many Islamic scientists. This approach is fundamental to which modern field?
questions.ex: The emphasis on observation, experimentation, and empirical evidence by Islamic scholars laid the groundwork for the modern scientific method.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is considered a pioneer in the field of sociology and historiography, known for his work 'Muqaddimah'?
questions.ex: Ibn Khaldun was a prominent historian and sociologist whose 'Muqaddimah' is considered a foundational text in these fields.

questions.q: The development of universities and centers of learning was a significant feature of the Islamic Golden Age. The Al-Qarawiyyin university, considered one of the oldest continuously operating universities in the world, is located in:
questions.ex: The Al-Qarawiyyin university in Fes, Morocco, founded in 859 CE, is recognized as one of the world's oldest universities.

questions.q: Islamic scholars made significant contributions to astronomy, including the construction of observatories and the refinement of astronomical tables. Which celestial body's movement was particularly studied?
questions.ex: Islamic astronomers made extensive observations and calculations related to the movement of the Moon, which was essential for determining the Islamic calendar and prayer times.

questions.q: The use of numerals we use today, often called Arabic numerals, was popularized in the West by Islamic scholars, but they originated from:
questions.ex: The numerals commonly known as Arabic numerals originated in India and were transmitted to the Arab world, where they were further developed and then introduced to Europe.

questions.q: Islamic physicians were pioneers in surgery and anesthesia. Which famous surgeon from Al-Andalus (Islamic Spain) developed numerous surgical instruments and procedures?
questions.ex: Al-Zahrawi, known as Albucasis in the West, was a renowned surgeon from Cordoba who authored a comprehensive medical encyclopedia that included a detailed section on surgery with illustrations of surgical instruments.

questions.q: The concept of hospitals as we know them today, with separate wards for different illnesses, originated in the Islamic world. What were these hospitals called?
questions.ex: Bimaristans were hospitals in the medieval Islamic world that provided medical care, often free of charge, and included features like separate wards and teaching facilities.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar made significant contributions to physics, particularly in the areas of mechanics and optics, and is credited with questioning Aristotle's ideas on motion?
questions.ex: Ibn al-Haytham conducted experiments on motion and challenged some of the prevailing Aristotelian physics, contributing to the development of mechanics.

questions.q: The translation movement during the Islamic Golden Age played a crucial role in preserving and transmitting ancient Greek, Roman, and other scientific texts. Which city was a major center for this translation work?
questions.ex: Baghdad, particularly the House of Wisdom, was a central hub for the translation movement, where scholars translated numerous scientific and philosophical works into Arabic.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his extensive work on pharmacology and the properties of various medicinal plants?
questions.ex: Ibn al-Baitar was a prominent botanist and pharmacist from Al-Andalus who compiled extensive works on medicinal plants and drugs.

questions.q: The development of spherical trigonometry was an important contribution of Islamic mathematicians. This was particularly useful for what application?
questions.ex: Spherical trigonometry was essential for solving problems related to celestial navigation and astronomical calculations, which were important for determining prayer times and direction.

questions.q: Islamic scholars made advancements in chemistry, moving beyond the practices of alchemy. Who is considered one of the pioneers of early chemistry, known for his emphasis on experimentation?
questions.ex: Jabir ibn Hayyan, known as Geber in the West, is considered one of the earliest figures in systematic chemical investigation and experimentation.

questions.q: The concept of the 'scientific paper' and peer review has roots in the practices of Islamic scholars who would review and comment on each other's work. This contributed to the advancement of:
questions.ex: The systematic approach to research, documentation, and peer review practiced by Islamic scholars contributed to the development of a rigorous scientific methodology.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his contributions to optics and the study of light, including the concept of the camera obscura?
questions.ex: Ibn al-Haytham's work on optics included the study of the camera obscura, explaining how light enters and forms an image.

questions.q: Islamic cartographers created accurate maps of the world known at the time. Which material was commonly used for creating these detailed maps?
questions.ex: The widespread adoption of paper technology from China in the Islamic world facilitated the creation of detailed maps and manuscripts.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his work on mechanics and engineering, describing various mechanical devices and automata?
questions.ex: Al-Jazari was a brilliant engineer and inventor known for his detailed descriptions and illustrations of various mechanical devices in his 'Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices'.

questions.q: The astronomical observations made by Islamic scholars in observatories like the Maragheh Observatory were highly accurate for their time and influenced later astronomers in Europe. These observations contributed to a better understanding of:
questions.ex: Islamic astronomers made precise observations of planetary movements, which led to the refinement of astronomical models and tables.

questions.q: Islamic scholars preserved and translated many works from ancient Greece, including the works of philosophers like Aristotle. This played a vital role in the transmission of classical knowledge to:
questions.ex: The translation movement in the Islamic world ensured the preservation and transmission of classical Greek philosophical and scientific texts, which were later translated into Latin and influenced the Renaissance in Europe.

questions.q: The development of hospitals in the Islamic world was not only for treating the sick but also served as centers for medical education. This combination of healthcare and teaching was a significant innovation in:
questions.ex: Islamic hospitals (Bimaristans) integrated patient care with medical teaching and research, establishing a model for medical institutions that was later adopted in other parts of the world.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive encyclopedia of pharmacology and materia medica, detailing the uses of various drugs and medicinal substances?
questions.ex: Ibn al-Baitar's work was a major contribution to the field of pharmacology, documenting a vast number of medicinal substances and their properties.

questions.q: The emphasis on observation and empirical evidence in the Islamic scientific tradition contributed to the development of which scientific field?
questions.ex: The focus on empirical observation and experimentation by Islamic scientists was a key factor in the development of experimental science.

questions.q: Islamic scholars made significant advancements in the field of optics, leading to a better understanding of:
questions.ex: Islamic contributions to optics, particularly by Ibn al-Haytham, revolutionized the understanding of how we see and the nature of light.

questions.q: The development of sophisticated water management systems, including irrigation techniques and canals, was a notable achievement in the Islamic world, particularly in areas with arid climates. This demonstrates advancements in:
questions.ex: Islamic engineers and agriculturalists developed advanced water management systems crucial for supporting agriculture in various regions.

questions.q: Which Islamic scholar is known for his work on mechanics and wrote a treatise on weights and balances?
questions.ex: Al-Khazini was a Persian physicist and astronomer known for his work on mechanics, including the theory of gravity and hydrostatics, detailed in his 'Book of the Balance of Wisdom'.

questions.q: Islamic scholars made important contributions to the field of zoology and botany, documenting various species and their characteristics. This was often linked to which other field of study?
questions.ex: Knowledge of plants and animals was often linked to medicine, as many substances used for treatment were derived from the natural world.

questions.q: The development of the concept of the algorithm, fundamental to modern computing, is attributed to the work of which Islamic scholar?
questions.ex: Al-Khwarizmi's work on arithmetic and algebra led to the development of systematic procedures for solving problems, which are the basis of algorithms.

questions.q: Islamic observatories were advanced institutions equipped with precise instruments for astronomical observations. These observatories were crucial for:
questions.ex: Islamic observatories were dedicated to the systematic observation and mapping of celestial bodies, contributing significantly to astronomy.

questions.q: The use of hospitals as teaching centers in the Islamic world fostered a system of medical education where students learned through practical experience and lectures. This approach was a precursor to modern:
questions.ex: The combination of theoretical teaching and practical training in Islamic hospitals laid the foundation for the structure of modern medical schools.

questions.q: Islamic scholars made significant contributions to the field of cartography, producing accurate maps that were used for navigation and trade. Which geographical feature was often depicted with great detail?
questions.ex: Islamic cartographers paid close attention to coastlines and trade routes, as accurate maps were vital for maritime travel and commerce.

questions.q: The introduction of paper manufacturing from China to the Islamic world had a profound impact on the dissemination of knowledge. This new technology facilitated the production of:
questions.ex: The availability of paper made it easier and cheaper to produce books and manuscripts, leading to a wider spread of literacy and knowledge.

questions.q: Islamic scholars translated and commented on philosophical works from ancient Greece, integrating them with Islamic thought. This intellectual activity contributed to the development of Islamic:
questions.ex: The engagement with Greek philosophy stimulated intellectual debate and contributed to the development of Islamic philosophy and theology.

questions.q: What is the basis of the Islamic calendar?
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar is a purely lunar calendar.

questions.q: How many months are there in the Islamic calendar?
questions.ex: There are 12 months in the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: What is the first month of the Islamic calendar?
questions.ex: Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: Which month is the month of fasting for Muslims?
questions.ex: Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and is the month of fasting.

questions.q: Which month is associated with the Hajj pilgrimage?
questions.ex: Dhul-Hijjah is the twelfth month and is when the Hajj pilgrimage takes place.

questions.q: The Islamic calendar is also known as the:
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar is also known as the Hijri calendar, named after the Hijra (migration) of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: The start of the Islamic calendar is marked by which event?
options: The first revelation of the Quran
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar began with the Hijra (migration) of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Medina in 622 CE.

questions.q: How many days are typically in a month of the Islamic calendar?
questions.ex: Islamic months alternate between 29 and 30 days, determined by the sighting of the new moon.

questions.q: Which month is considered one of the four sacred months in Islam?
questions.ex: Rajab is one of the four sacred months in Islam, during which warfare is forbidden.

questions.q: Laylat al-Qadr (Night of Power) falls in which month?
questions.ex: Laylat al-Qadr is believed to occur during the last ten nights of Ramadan.

questions.q: Eid al-Fitr is celebrated after the completion of which month?
questions.ex: Eid al-Fitr is celebrated on the first day of Shawwal, after the month of Ramadan.

questions.q: Eid al-Adha is celebrated during which month?
questions.ex: Eid al-Adha is celebrated during the month of Dhul-Hijjah, coinciding with the Hajj pilgrimage.

questions.q: Which month contains the day of Ashura?
questions.ex: The day of Ashura is the tenth day of Muharram.

questions.q: The Islamic calendar is approximately how many days shorter than the Gregorian calendar?
questions.ex: The lunar Islamic year is approximately 354 or 355 days long, which is about 10 to 11 days shorter than the solar Gregorian year.

questions.q: The sighting of the new moon is important for determining the start of which of the following?
questions.ex: The start of each Islamic month is determined by the sighting of the new moon.

questions.q: Which month is known as the 'month of migration'?
questions.ex: Safar is the second month and is sometimes referred to in relation to the Hijra, although Muharram is the first month of the calendar established after the Hijra.

questions.q: The month of Rabi' al-Awwal is significant for Muslims because:
options: It is the month of Hajj
It is the month of fasting
It is the month of the Prophet's birth
It is the first month of the year
questions.ex: Rabi' al-Awwal is widely believed to be the month of the birth of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

questions.q: Which month comes immediately after Ramadan?
questions.ex: Shawwal comes immediately after Ramadan.

questions.q: Which month precedes Dhul-Hijjah?
questions.ex: Dhul-Qa'dah is the eleventh month and precedes Dhul-Hijjah.

questions.q: The event of Isra and Mi'raj is traditionally believed to have occurred in which month?
questions.ex: The event of Isra and Mi'raj (the Prophet's Night Journey and Ascension) is traditionally believed to have occurred in the month of Rajab.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a sacred month in Islam?
questions.ex: The four sacred months are Muharram, Rajab, Dhul-Qa'dah, and Dhul-Hijjah.

questions.q: The Islamic calendar is primarily used for:
options: Determining Islamic holy days and rituals
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar is primarily used to determine the dates of Islamic holy days, festivals, and rituals.

questions.q: The word 'Hijri' in Hijri calendar refers to:
questions.ex: Hijri refers to the Hijra, the migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Medina.

questions.q: Which month is known for the beginning of the Hajj season?
questions.ex: The Hajj rituals primarily take place during the first ten days of Dhul-Hijjah.

questions.q: The tenth day of Muharram is known as:
questions.ex: The tenth day of Muharram is the day of Ashura.

questions.q: Which month is considered a preparatory month for Ramadan?
questions.ex: Sha'ban is the month immediately preceding Ramadan and is often seen as a time for preparation.

questions.q: The Islamic year is shorter than the Gregorian year, which means Islamic months and holidays appear to shift how in the Gregorian calendar?
options: Backward by about 10-11 days each year
Forward by about 10-11 days each year
questions.ex: Since the Islamic year is shorter, Islamic months and holidays shift backward by approximately 10-11 days each year in the Gregorian calendar.

questions.q: The practice of fasting is obligatory during which month?
questions.ex: Fasting during the month of Ramadan is one of the Five Pillars of Islam and is obligatory for adult Muslims who are able.

questions.q: The historical event of the Battle of Badr occurred in which month?
questions.ex: The Battle of Badr took place in the month of Ramadan in the 2nd year of the Hijra.

questions.q: Which month follows Rabi' al-Awwal?
questions.ex: Rabi' al-Thani (or Rabi' al-Akhir) follows Rabi' al-Awwal.

questions.q: The number of days in a lunar month is determined by:
options: The sighting of the new crescent moon
questions.ex: The start of each lunar month in the Islamic calendar is determined by the sighting of the new crescent moon.

questions.q: Which month comes before Sha'ban?
questions.ex: Rajab is the month that comes before Sha'ban.

questions.q: The months of the Islamic calendar are part of which type of calendar system?
questions.ex: The Islamic calendar is a purely lunar calendar, meaning its months are based on the cycles of the moon.

questions.q: Which month is known as the 'month of Hajj'?
questions.ex: Dhul-Hijjah is the month during which the Hajj pilgrimage is performed.

questions.q: The fasting month of Ramadan can occur in different seasons of the solar year because:
options: It is based on the sun
It is a fixed number of days
The lunar year is shorter than the solar year
It depends on the global Muslim population
questions.ex: Since the Islamic lunar year is shorter than the solar year, the month of Ramadan cycles through all seasons over time.

questions.q: Which of the following months is NOT considered one of the sacred months?
questions.ex: Safar is not one of the four sacred months.

questions.q: The Islamic calendar is also referenced as:
questions.ex: Anno Hegirae (AH) is the Latin term for 'in the year of the Hijra' and is used to denote years in the Islamic calendar.

questions.q: Hajj is obligatory for every Muslim who is:
options: Both physically fit and financially able
questions.ex: Hajj is obligatory for adult Muslims who are physically and financially capable of undertaking the journey.

questions.q: Umrah can be performed at any time of the year, except for certain days during:
questions.ex: Umrah is permissible throughout the year, but it is generally not performed during the days of Hajj (specifically the 8th to 13th of Dhu al-Hijjah).

questions.q: The circling of the Kaaba seven times is known as:
questions.ex: Tawaf is the ritual of circling the Kaaba seven times counter-clockwise.

questions.q: The running between the hills of Safa and Marwa seven times is known as:
questions.ex: Sa'i is the ritual of walking or running between the hills of Safa and Marwa seven times.

questions.q: What is the state of ritual purity assumed before performing Hajj or Umrah called?
questions.ex: Ihram is the sacred state a Muslim enters to perform Hajj or Umrah, marked by specific clothing and restrictions.

questions.q: On which day of Dhu al-Hijjah does the main ritual of Hajj, the standing at Arafat, take place?
questions.ex: The standing at Arafat (Wuquf) is the most crucial ritual of Hajj and occurs on the 9th of Dhu al-Hijjah.

questions.q: The throwing of stones at pillars representing Satan is called:
questions.ex: Ramy al-Jamarat is the stoning of pillars symbolizing Satan during Hajj.

questions.q: After completing the rituals, male pilgrims shave their heads, and female pilgrims cut a small portion of their hair. This is called:
questions.ex: Halq (shaving the head) for men and Taqsir (trimming the hair) for women are done after completing the Hajj or Umrah rituals.

questions.q: The Kaaba is located in which city?
questions.ex: The Kaaba, the most sacred site in Islam, is located in Mecca.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a pillar of Hajj?
questions.ex: Stoning of the Jamarat is an important ritual of Hajj, but the pillars of Hajj are Ihram, Tawaf al-Ifadah, and Wuquf at Arafat.

questions.q: The farewell Tawaf (Tawaf al-Wida) is performed:
options: Before entering the state of Ihram
questions.ex: Tawaf al-Wida is the final Tawaf performed by pilgrims just before leaving Mecca.

questions.q: The journey from Mecca to Medina during Hajj is part of the obligatory rituals. True or False?
questions.ex: The visit to Medina is not an obligatory part of Hajj, although it is highly recommended.

questions.q: What is the minimum age for a Muslim to be obligated to perform Hajj?
questions.ex: Hajj is obligatory for Muslims who have reached puberty.

questions.q: The area around the Kaaba where Tawaf is performed is called the:
questions.ex: The Masjid al-Haram is the Grand Mosque in Mecca that surrounds the Kaaba, where Tawaf is performed.

questions.q: What is the significance of the plain of Arafat?
options: It is where the stoning of Satan takes place
It is where pilgrims spend the night under the open sky
It is where pilgrims stand in intense devotion and prayer
It is where the sacrifice is offered
questions.ex: The standing at Arafat is the peak of Hajj, a day of intense prayer, repentance, and seeking forgiveness.

questions.q: The night spent in Muzdalifah after Arafat is for the purpose of:
questions.ex: Pilgrims spend the night in Muzdalifah and collect pebbles for the stoning ritual.

questions.q: The sacrificing of an animal during Hajj is known as:
questions.ex: Qurbani or Hady is the sacrifice of an animal during Hajj, symbolizing Prophet Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of performing Hajj?
options: To seek forgiveness and spiritual purification
questions.ex: The primary purpose of Hajj is to fulfill a religious obligation, seek forgiveness from Allah, and achieve spiritual purification.

questions.q: During Ihram, which of the following is NOT permitted for men?
questions.ex: Men in Ihram are not allowed to wear stitched clothing.

questions.q: During Ihram, which of the following is NOT permitted for women?
options: Wearing a veil that covers the face
questions.ex: Women in Ihram should not cover their faces with a veil, although they can cover their hair.

questions.q: The drink provided from the well of Zamzam is considered:
questions.ex: Zamzam water is considered sacred and has a special significance in Islam.

questions.q: What is the recommended number of days to stay in Mina during Hajj after the day of Arafat?
questions.ex: Pilgrims typically stay in Mina for two or three days after the day of Arafat to perform the stoning ritual.

questions.q: The place where pilgrims spend the night under the open sky after Arafat is called:
questions.ex: Muzdalifah is the open plain where pilgrims spend the night after leaving Arafat.

questions.q: What is the 'Kissing of the Black Stone' (Al-Hajar al-Aswad) a symbol of?
options: Following the Sunnah of the Prophet (PBUH)
Showing respect to a historical artifact
questions.ex: Kissing or touching the Black Stone is a Sunnah of the Prophet (PBUH), symbolizing allegiance to Allah.

questions.q: The area within the Masjid al-Haram that is considered a part of the Kaaba is:
questions.ex: The Hateem (or Hijr Ismail) is a semi-circular wall adjacent to the Kaaba, considered part of it.
